The movie will have a simultaneous release in cinemas and on streaming platforms.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'simultaneus', from 'simul' (at the same time).

content.meaning_en: An internal or external framework of bone, cartilage, or other rigid material supporting or protecting the body of an animal or plant.
usage_sentences: The human skeleton is made up of 206 bones.
Archaeologists unearthed the complete skeleton of a mammoth.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A narrow opening or groove in something. (Verb) - Fit into a slot.
usage_sentences: Please insert your ticket into the slot on the machine.
I've managed to find a slot in my schedule for a meeting.
content.origin: From Old French 'esclot', the hollow of the breastbone.

content.meaning_en: The study of the development, structure, and functioning of human society.
usage_sentences: She is studying sociology to understand the causes of social inequality.
Sociology examines how people interact in groups.

content.meaning_en: The state or situation of being alone.
usage_sentences: He enjoys the peace and solitude of the countryside.
After a busy week, she looked forward to a weekend of solitude.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Able to pay one's debts. (Noun) - The liquid in which a solute is dissolved to form a solution.
usage_sentences: The company managed to remain solvent during the economic crisis.
Water is often called the universal solvent.

content.meaning_en: The forming of a theory or conjecture without firm evidence.
usage_sentences: There has been much speculation in the media about the couple's relationship.
His theory is pure speculation and is not supported by any facts.

content.meaning_en: A person who speaks for a group or organization.
usage_sentences: A spokesman for the company issued a statement to the press.
The government spokesman refused to comment on the matter.
content.origin: A compound of 'spoke' (past tense of speak) and 'man'.

content.meaning_en: Plural form of Spokesman.
usage_sentences: Spokespersons from both political parties debated the issue on television.
The company appointed two spokespersons to handle media inquiries.

content.meaning_en: A printed or computer-generated record of the balance in an account.
usage_sentences: I receive a monthly bank statement showing all my transactions.
Please check your credit card statement for any errors.
content.origin: From the verb 'state', from Latin 'stare' (to stand).

content.meaning_en: Not able to produce children or young.
usage_sentences: The doctor confirmed that the infection had left him sterile.
Surgical instruments must be completely sterile before use.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining. (Adjective) - Enduring hardship without showing feelings or complaining.
usage_sentences: He remained stoic throughout the long and painful ordeal.
She was a true stoic, never complaining despite her illness.
content.origin: From Greek 'Stōïkos', from 'Stoa (Poikilē)' (Painted Porch), the place in Athens where the philosopher Zeno taught.

content.meaning_en: The endurance of pain or hardship without a display of feelings and without complaint.
usage_sentences: He faced the difficult situation with admirable stoicism.
Stoicism was an ancient Greek school of philosophy.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - Mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or demanding circumstances. (Verb) - Subject to stress or tension.
usage_sentences: Working long hours can cause a lot of stress.
The teacher stressed the importance of studying for the exam.

content.meaning_en: Demanding that rules concerning behavior are obeyed and observed.
usage_sentences: The school has a strict policy against bullying.
Her parents were very strict when she was a child.

content.meaning_en: Arrange to receive something regularly by paying a subscription.
usage_sentences: I subscribe to several magazines about science and technology.
You can subscribe to our YouTube channel to get notifications for new videos.

content.meaning_en: (Especially of a change or distinction) so delicate or fine as to be difficult to perceive or describe.
usage_sentences: There was a subtle change in his tone of voice.
The artist is known for her subtle use of color.
content.origin: From Old French 'soutil', from Latin 'subtilis' (fine, delicate).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - The act of intentionally causing one's own death. (Verb) - Intentionally cause one's own death.
usage_sentences: The note he left made it clear that his death was a suicide.
Mental health support is crucial in preventing suicide.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).
content.origin: From modern Latin 'suicidium', from 'sui' (of oneself) and '-cidium' (a killing).

content.meaning_en: A brief statement or account of the main points of something.
usage_sentences: Please provide a one-page summary of the report.
In summary, the project was a great success.

content.meaning_en: Existing or occurring at or on the surface.
usage_sentences: The doctor said the wound was only superficial and didn't require stitches.
He has only a superficial knowledge of the subject.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Of the highest quality or degree. (Noun) - An exaggerated or hyperbolical expression of praise.
usage_sentences: The chef's cooking was of superlative quality.
In grammar, 'best' is the superlative form of 'good'.

content.meaning_en: Involving or denoting a speed greater than that of sound.
usage_sentences: The Concorde was a famous supersonic passenger jet.
The fighter jet created a sonic boom as it flew at supersonic speeds.

content.meaning_en: Excessively credulous belief in and reverence for supernatural beings.
usage_sentences: It's a common superstition that breaking a mirror brings seven years of bad luck.
He dismissed her fears as mere superstition.
content.origin: From Latin 'superstitio(n-)', from 'superstare' (to stand over in awe).

content.meaning_en: The state or condition of being superior to all others in authority, power, or status.
usage_sentences: The company has achieved supremacy in the global market.
The battle was fought to establish naval supremacy.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A sudden large increase, typically temporary. (Verb) - (of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
usage_sentences: There has been a surge in demand for electric cars.
The crowd surged forward to get a better view.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - An amount of something left over when requirements have been met; an excess of production or supply over demand. (Adjective) - More than what is needed or used; excess.
usage_sentences: The country has a trade surplus, exporting more than it imports.
Any surplus food from the event will be donated to charity.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Stop resisting to an enemy or opponent and submit to their authority. (Noun) - The action of surrendering.
usage_sentences: The enemy forces were finally forced to surrender.
He refused to surrender his dreams, despite the setbacks.

content.meaning_en: A weapon with a long metal blade and a hilt with a hand guard, used for thrusting or striking.
usage_sentences: The knight drew his long sword from its scabbard.
The museum displayed a collection of ancient swords.
content.origin: From Old English 'sweord', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A unit of pronunciation having one vowel sound, with or without surrounding consonants, forming the whole or a part of a word.
usage_sentences: The word 'water' has two syllables: 'wa-' and '-ter'.
A haiku is a Japanese poem of three phrases, composed of 5, 7, and 5 syllables.

content.meaning_en: An instance of a form of reasoning in which a conclusion is drawn from two given or assumed propositions (premises).
usage_sentences: 'All men are mortal; Socrates is a man; therefore, Socrates is mortal' is a famous syllogism.
In logic class, we studied the structure of a valid syllogism.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - (of a substance) made by chemical synthesis, especially to imitate a natural product. (Noun) - A synthetic material or product.
usage_sentences: Nylon and polyester are examples of synthetic fabrics.
The perfume has a synthetic floral scent.

content.meaning_en: The aquatic larval stage of a frog or toad.
usage_sentences: The children collected tadpoles from the pond in a jar.
A tadpole gradually transforms into a frog through metamorphosis.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A permanent mark or design made on the skin by a process of pricking and inserting indelible pigments. (Verb) - Mark (skin) with tattoos.
usage_sentences: He has a large dragon tattoo on his back.
She decided to get a small tattoo on her wrist.

content.meaning_en: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry.
usage_sentences: Modern technology has completely changed the way we live and work.
He is studying information technology at college.

content.meaning_en: The supposed communication of thoughts or ideas by means other than the known senses.
usage_sentences: The twins claimed they could communicate through telepathy.
There is no scientific evidence to prove that telepathy exists.

content.meaning_en: Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.
usage_sentences: He got a temporary job for the summer.
The road closure is only temporary and will be lifted tomorrow.

content.meaning_en: The final point in space or time; the end of something.
usage_sentences: The Grand Central Terminal is a famous railway terminus in New York.
The agreement marked the terminus of the long and difficult negotiations.

content.meaning_en: Formal statement testifying to someone's character and qualifications, or to the value and quality of goods or services.
usage_sentences: The website was full of glowing testimonials from satisfied customers.
He provided several testimonials from his previous employers.

content.meaning_en: A person who believes in the existence of a god or gods.
usage_sentences: In contrast to an atheist, a theist believes in a higher power.
Her philosophical journey led her from atheism to becoming a theist.

content.meaning_en: Showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened.
usage_sentences: The timid child was afraid to speak in front of the class.
A timid mouse peeked out from its hole.

content.meaning_en: Extremely small.
usage_sentences: The baby had tiny fingers and toes.
I found a tiny crack in the teacup.
content.origin: From Middle English, of unknown origin.

content.meaning_en: Poisonous.
usage_sentences: The factory was fined for releasing toxic waste into the river.
Some mushrooms are toxic and should not be eaten.
content.origin: From late Latin 'toxicus', from Greek 'toxikon (pharmakon)' ([poison] for arrows).

content.meaning_en: A person who betrays a friend, country, principle, etc.
usage_sentences: He was considered a traitor for selling military secrets to the enemy.
Benedict Arnold is a famous traitor in American history.
content.origin: From Old French 'traitour', from Latin 'traditor', from 'tradere' (to hand over).

content.meaning_en: Put (thoughts, speech, or data) into written or printed form.
usage_sentences: She was hired to transcribe the recorded interviews.
The historian's job was to transcribe the ancient manuscript.

content.meaning_en: An apparatus for reducing or increasing the voltage of an alternating current.
usage_sentences: A large transformer is used at the power station to change the voltage.
The electrician had to replace the faulty transformer.
content.origin: From the verb 'transform', from Latin 'transformare' (to change shape).

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A river or stream flowing into a larger river or lake.
usage_sentences: The Yamuna is a major tributary of the Ganges river.
Several small tributaries feed into the main river.

content.meaning_en: Difficult to deal with or do; requiring skill or care.
usage_sentences: It was a tricky question, and he wasn't sure how to answer.
Assembling the new furniture proved to be a tricky task.

content.meaning_en: Recurring every three years.
usage_sentences: The organization holds a triennial conference for all its members.
It's a triennial event, so the next one will be in 2028.

content.meaning_en: A three-legged stand for supporting a camera or other apparatus.
usage_sentences: He mounted the camera on a tripod to keep it steady.
A tripod is essential for taking long-exposure photographs at night.

content.meaning_en: Of little value or importance.
usage_sentences: Don't waste my time with such trivial matters.
They argued over a trivial detail that didn't affect the main plan.
content.origin: From Latin 'trivialis', from 'trivium' (place where three roads meet).

content.meaning_en: A company of dancers, actors, or other entertainers who tour to different venues.
usage_sentences: A troupe of traveling actors performed Shakespeare in the park.
She is a member of a famous dance troupe.

content.meaning_en: A long high sea wave caused by an earthquake, submarine landslide, or other disturbance.
usage_sentences: The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami was a devastating natural disaster.
Coastal communities were warned to evacuate due to the tsunami risk.

content.meaning_en: Two children or animals born at the same birth.
usage_sentences: She gave birth to identical twins, a boy and a girl.
The twins look so much alike that it's hard to tell them apart.

content.meaning_en: A cruel and oppressive ruler.
usage_sentences: The people rose up in rebellion against the tyrant.
He ruled his company like a tyrant, with absolute control.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or characteristic of all people or things in the world or in a particular group; applicable to all cases.
usage_sentences: Music is often called the universal language.
The desire for happiness is a universal human trait.

content.meaning_en: Impossible to know.
usage_sentences: The exact number of stars in the universe is unknowable.
The future is ultimately unknowable.

content.meaning_en: An upward push or force.
usage_sentences: An object submerged in water experiences an upward force called upthrust.
Geological upthrust created the mountain range over millions of years.

content.meaning_en: The action or practice of lending money at unreasonably high rates of interest.
usage_sentences: Loan sharks are notorious for practicing usury.
Some ancient laws made usury a crime.
content.origin: From Latin 'usura', meaning 'a charge for the use of money'.

content.meaning_en: The state of being useful, profitable, or beneficial.
usage_sentences: This tool has a great deal of utility in the kitchen.
You need to pay your monthly utility bills, like electricity and water.

content.meaning_en: A low area of land between hills or mountains, typically with a river or stream flowing through it.
usage_sentences: The small village was nestled in a picturesque mountain valley.
A river runs through the bottom of the valley.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who does not eat any food derived from animals and who typically abstains from using other animal products.
usage_sentences: As a strict vegan, she does not eat meat, dairy, or eggs.
The restaurant has a special menu for vegan customers.
content.origin: Coined in 1944 by Donald Watson, from the beginning and end of 'vegetarian'.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who does not eat meat, and sometimes other animal products. (Adjective) - Relating to vegetarians or vegetarianism.
usage_sentences: My sister has been a vegetarian for over ten years.
The restaurant offers several delicious vegetarian options.

content.meaning_en: Regard with great respect; revere.
usage_sentences: The local people venerate their ancestors with annual ceremonies.
She is a writer who is venerated by her readers.

content.meaning_en: Seeking to harm someone in return for perceived injury.
usage_sentences: He had a vengeful look in his eyes after being betrayed.
She was too kind to be a vengeful person.
content.origin: From 'vengeance', from Old French 'vengeance', from 'venger' (to avenge).

content.meaning_en: The quality of using more words than needed; wordiness.
usage_sentences: The report was criticized for its unnecessary verbosity.
His verbosity made his speeches long and boring.

content.meaning_en: A decision on a disputed issue in a civil or criminal case or an inquest.
usage_sentences: The jury returned a verdict of guilty.
The public is waiting for the final verdict in the high-profile case.
content.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'verdit', from Old French 'voir' (true) and 'dit' (saying).

content.meaning_en: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
usage_sentences: He is a versatile actor who is equally good in comedy and drama.
A smartphone is a very versatile device with many different functions.

content.meaning_en: An animal of a large group distinguished by the possession of a backbone or spinal column.
usage_sentences: Mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fishes are all vertebrates.
The evolution of vertebrates was a major step in the history of life.

content.meaning_en: A character whose evil actions or motives are important to the plot.
usage_sentences: In every good story, the hero must defeat the villain.
He was cast as the villain in the new action movie.
content.origin: From Old French 'vilein', originally meaning 'peasant' or 'farm worker'.

content.meaning_en: Behavior showing high moral standards.
usage_sentences: Patience is a virtue that not everyone possesses.
He was a man of great virtue and integrity.
content.origin: From Latin 'virtus', meaning 'valor, merit, moral perfection'.

content.meaning_en: (Adjective) - Thinking about or planning the future with imagination or wisdom. (Noun) - A person with original ideas about what the future will or could be like.
usage_sentences: Steve Jobs was a visionary who revolutionized the technology industry.
The architect had a visionary plan to redesign the city center.

content.meaning_en: Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse.
usage_sentences: The political situation in the country is highly volatile.
Gasoline is a volatile substance that evaporates quickly.

content.meaning_en: Done, given, or acting of one's own free will.
usage_sentences: Attendance at the workshop is completely voluntary.
She makes a voluntary contribution to the charity every month.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A person who freely offers to take part in an enterprise or undertake a task. (Verb) - Freely offer to do something.
usage_sentences: The organization is looking for a volunteer to help with fundraising.
He volunteered to coach the children's football team.

content.meaning_en: Susceptible to physical or emotional attack or harm.
usage_sentences: Young children are especially vulnerable to illness.
The new computer system is vulnerable to cyber attacks.

content.meaning_en: Walk or move in a leisurely, rambling way.
usage_sentences: We spent the afternoon wandering through the streets of the old town.
His mind began to wander during the long lecture.
content.origin: From Old English 'wandrian', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: (Noun) - A document issued by a legal or government official authorizing the police or some other body to make an arrest, search premises, or carry out some other action.
usage_sentences: The police had a warrant to search the suspect's house.
His strange behavior warrants further investigation.
content.origin: From Old Northern French 'warant', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A cascade of water falling from a height, formed when a river or stream flows over a precipice or steep incline.
usage_sentences: We hiked through the forest to see the spectacular waterfall.
The sound of the waterfall was deafening.

content.meaning_en: (Verb) - Speak very softly using one's breath without vibration of the vocal cords, especially for secrecy. (Noun) - A soft, quiet, or hushed sound.
usage_sentences: She leaned over to whisper a secret in his ear.
They spoke in whispers so as not to wake the baby.
content.origin: From Old English 'hwisprian', of imitative origin.

content.meaning_en: A person or company that sells goods in large quantities at low prices, typically to retailers.
usage_sentences: The shop buys its products directly from the wholesaler.
A wholesaler acts as a middleman between the manufacturer and the retailer.

content.meaning_en: A woman who has lost her husband by death and has not married again.
usage_sentences: She became a widow at a young age when her husband died in the war.
The charity provides support for widows and their children.
content.origin: From Old English 'widewe', of Indo-European origin.

content.meaning_en: A man who has lost his wife by death and has not married again.
usage_sentences: He has been a widower for many years but has never remarried.
The old widower was very lonely after his wife passed away.

content.meaning_en: Intentionally or deliberately.
usage_sentences: He wilfully ignored the instructions and did it his own way.
She was accused of wilfully damaging the property.
content.origin: From the adjective 'wilful', a compound of 'will' and '-ful'.

content.meaning_en: Become less intense or severe; subside; decrease.
content.meaning_hi: कम प्रभावी हो जाना; कम होना; घटना
usage_sentences: After a few hours, the storm began to abate, and the winds calmed down.
The medicine should help to abate the pain from your headache.
content.origin: From Old French 'abatre' meaning 'to beat down', from Latin 'battuere' (to beat).

content.meaning_en: A slaughterhouse; a place where animals are killed for food.
usage_sentences: The meat processing plant included a large, modern abattoir.
Regulations ensure that abattoirs maintain high standards of hygiene.

content.meaning_en: The head or superior of an abbey or monastery for men.
usage_sentences: The abbot was responsible for the spiritual and administrative well-being of the monastery.
Brother Thomas was elected as the new abbot by the monks.
content.origin: From late Latin 'abbas', from Greek, based on Aramaic 'abba' meaning 'father'.

content.meaning_en: To give up a position of power, right, or throne, especially voluntarily.
usage_sentences: King Edward VIII had to abdicate the throne to marry the woman he loved.
The CEO decided to abdicate his position after the company's poor performance.

content.meaning_en: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
content.meaning_hi: पथ से भटक जाना; सामान्य से विचलन
usage_sentences: The single poor grade on his report card was an aberration from his usual high marks.
Her sudden outburst of anger was an aberration that surprised everyone.

content.meaning_en: The act of washing oneself, often as a religious rite.
usage_sentences: Before entering the temple, the pilgrims performed their ritual ablutions.
His morning routine included a quick ablution and prayer.

content.meaning_en: To renounce or reject something desired or valuable; to deny oneself things.
usage_sentences: The monk chose to abnegate all worldly pleasures for a life of spiritual devotion.
She had to abnegate her personal ambitions to care for her family.

content.meaning_en: To formally put an end to a system, practice, or institution.
usage_sentences: The new law aims to abolish child labor completely.
Abraham Lincoln is famous for his role in abolishing slavery in the United States.

content.meaning_en: The original inhabitants of a country or region.
usage_sentences: The culture of the Australian Aborigines is one of the oldest in the world.
The rights of the aborigines were discussed at the international conference.
content.origin: From Latin 'ab origine', meaning 'from the beginning'.

content.meaning_en: To shorten a piece of writing (book, speech, etc.) without losing the essential meaning.
usage_sentences: The publisher decided to abridge the classic novel to make it more accessible to young readers.
He had to abridge his speech to fit the ten-minute time limit.
content.origin: From Old French 'abregier', from Latin 'abbreviare' (to shorten).

content.meaning_en: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
usage_sentences: The parliament voted to abrogate the unpopular tax law.
A new treaty was signed to abrogate all previous agreements.

content.meaning_en: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
usage_sentences: The cashier was caught on video as he tried to abscond with the day's earnings.
The prisoner managed to abscond from the minimum-security facility.

content.meaning_en: Formal release from guilt, obligation, or punishment; forgiveness, especially in a religious context.
usage_sentences: After his confession, the priest granted him absolution.
The new evidence led to her complete absolution from all charges.

content.meaning_en: Difficult to understand; obscure; perplexing.
usage_sentences: The professor's lecture on philosophy was too abstruse for me to follow.
He delved into abstruse theories that few could comprehend.

content.meaning_en: Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate; ridiculous.
usage_sentences: The suggestion that we could finish the project in one day was completely absurd.
She has a wonderfully absurd sense of humor.

content.meaning_en: To make more noticeable or prominent; emphasize.
usage_sentences: The new haircut seemed to accentuate her high cheekbones.
The report should accentuate the positive outcomes of the research.

content.meaning_en: An award or privilege granted as a special honour or as an acknowledgement of merit.
usage_sentences: Receiving the Nobel Prize is the highest accolade a scientist can achieve.
The film received numerous accolades from critics.
content.origin: From French, literally 'an embrace', from Latin 'ad' (to) + 'collum' (neck).

content.meaning_en: A person who helps another commit a crime or wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: The driver of the getaway car was charged as an accomplice to the bank robbery.
She denied being an accomplice, claiming she knew nothing of the plan.

content.meaning_en: (Especially of a comment or style of speaking) sharp and forthright; tasting sour or bitter.
usage_sentences: He was known for his acerbic wit and harsh criticism.
Her acerbic review of the new play was widely quoted.

content.meaning_en: The properties or qualities of a room or building that determine how sound is transmitted in it.
usage_sentences: The new concert hall is famous for its perfect acoustics.
An expert in acoustics was hired to design the recording studio.

content.meaning_en: To free (someone) from a criminal charge by a verdict of not guilty.
usage_sentences: The jury deliberated for hours before deciding to acquit the defendant.
New evidence came to light, which helped acquit the wrongly convicted man.
content.origin: From Old French 'acquiter', meaning 'to pay a debt'.

content.meaning_en: An entertainer who performs spectacular gymnastic feats.
usage_sentences: The circus acrobat performed a breathtaking routine on the trapeze.
You need incredible strength and balance to be an acrobat.
content.origin: From Greek 'akrobatēs', meaning 'one who walks on tiptoe'.

content.meaning_en: An abbreviation formed from the initial letters of other words and pronounced as a word.
usage_sentences: NASA is an acronym for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The word 'scuba' is actually an acronym for 'Self-Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus'.

content.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of heights.
usage_sentences: Due to his acrophobia, he couldn't even stand on the balcony of his apartment.
She sought therapy to overcome her debilitating acrophobia.
content.note: Suffix '-phobia' denotes an extreme or irrational fear.

content.meaning_en: The ability to make good judgements and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain.
usage_sentences: Her business acumen helped the company to thrive in a competitive market.
He possessed a sharp political acumen that made him a formidable opponent.

content.meaning_en: An item of additional material added at the end of a book or other publication.
usage_sentences: The book included an addendum with updated research findings.
Please see the addendum for a list of corrections to the original text.

content.meaning_en: A person who is physically or mentally dependent on a particular substance or activity.
usage_sentences: He is a self-confessed coffee addict who can't start his day without it.
The clinic provides support for those trying to overcome being a drug addict.

content.meaning_en: To stick fast to (a surface or substance); to believe in and follow the practices of.
usage_sentences: All contestants must adhere to the rules of the competition.
The wet poster did not adhere to the wall properly.

content.meaning_en: The period following the onset of puberty during which a young person develops from a child into an adult.
usage_sentences: The transition from childhood to adulthood during adolescence can be difficult.
He wrote a book about the challenges of adolescence.

content.meaning_en: An extremely handsome young man (from Greek mythology).
usage_sentences: With his perfect physique and charming smile, he was the Adonis of the gym.
The lead actor in the film was an Adonis who captured many hearts.
content.origin: From Adonis, a beautiful youth in Greek mythology beloved by the goddess Aphrodite.

content.meaning_en: The action of making something poorer in quality by adding another substance.
usage_sentences: The government has strict laws against the adulteration of food products.
Adulteration of honey with sugar syrup is a common fraudulent practice.

content.meaning_en: Voluntary sexual intercourse between a married person and a person who is not their spouse.
usage_sentences: She filed for divorce after discovering her husband's adultery.
In many historical dramas, adultery is a central theme.

content.meaning_en: Willing to take risks or to try out new methods, ideas, or experiences.
usage_sentences: As an adventurous traveler, he preferred exploring remote jungles to staying in luxury resorts.
She has an adventurous spirit and is always looking for her next challenge.
content.origin: From 'adventure', derived from Latin 'adventura' (a thing about to happen).

content.meaning_en: A person who publicly supports a particular cause; a lawyer who pleads cases.
usage_sentences: She is a passionate advocate for animal rights.
The advocate presented a compelling argument to the jury.

content.meaning_en: Existing, happening, or operating in the air.
usage_sentences: The documentary featured breathtaking aerial views of the Grand Canyon.
The circus had a stunning aerial acrobatics show.

content.meaning_en: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
usage_sentences: The Japanese garden was designed with a minimalist aesthetic.
From an aesthetic point of view, the painting was a masterpiece.

content.meaning_en: A list of items to be discussed at a formal meeting.
usage_sentences: The committee chairman distributed the agenda before the meeting began.
Improving customer service is the first item on our agenda today.

content.meaning_en: To increase the power, status, or wealth of.
usage_sentences: The dictator sought to aggrandize his own image through massive building projects.
He was accused of using his position to aggrandize himself.

content.meaning_en: A person who believes that nothing is known or can be known of the existence or nature of God.
usage_sentences: While not an atheist, she identified as an agnostic, believing proof of God is unknowable.
The agnostic philosopher argued that faith and belief are separate from empirical knowledge.

content.meaning_en: Extreme physical or mental suffering.
usage_sentences: He was in agony after twisting his ankle.
She suffered the agony of waiting for the test results.

content.meaning_en: The medieval forerunner of chemistry, based on the supposed transformation of matter.
usage_sentences: Practitioners of alchemy attempted to turn common metals into gold.
The book was about the history of alchemy and its influence on science.
content.origin: From Arabic 'al-kīmiyā', from Greek 'khēmia' (art of transmuting metals).

content.meaning_en: A substance that is poisonous to algae and used to kill them.
usage_sentences: To keep the swimming pool clean, you need to add algaecide regularly.
The overuse of algaecide can be harmful to other aquatic life.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).

content.meaning_en: An abnormal or irrational fear of pain.
usage_sentences: His algophobia made him avoid visiting the doctor, even when he was sick.
A person with algophobia might have an extreme reaction to even a minor injury.
content.note: Suffix '-phobia' denotes an extreme or irrational fear.

content.meaning_en: Belonging to a foreign country; unfamiliar; supposedly from another world.
usage_sentences: The science fiction movie depicted an invasion by hostile aliens.
The concept of personal freedom was alien to the oppressed people.

content.meaning_en: Financial support that a person is ordered by a court to give to their spouse during separation or following divorce.
usage_sentences: The court ordered him to pay a significant amount of alimony to his ex-wife.
She relied on alimony payments to support herself after the divorce.

content.meaning_en: A story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one.
usage_sentences: Plato's 'Allegory of the Cave' is a famous philosophical allegory about perception and reality.
The novel is an allegory for the dangers of totalitarianism.
content.origin: From Greek 'allēgoria', from 'allos' (other) + 'agoreuein' (to speak in public).

content.meaning_en: The occurrence of the same letter or sound at the beginning of adjacent or closely connected words.
usage_sentences: The phrase 'sweet birds sang' is an example of alliteration.
Poets often use alliteration to create a musical effect in their writing.

content.meaning_en: A deposit of clay, silt, sand, and gravel left by flowing streams, typically producing fertile soil.
usage_sentences: The river valley is covered in rich alluvium, making it ideal for farming.
Geologists studied the layers of alluvium to understand the river's history.

content.meaning_en: The school, college, or university that one once attended.
usage_sentences: He made a generous donation to his alma mater to fund a new library.
During the reunion, alumni shared fond memories of their alma mater.

content.meaning_en: An annual calendar containing important dates and statistical information.
usage_sentences: The farmer's almanac predicted a harsh winter.
I looked up the time of the sunrise in the almanac.
content.origin: From late Latin 'almanachus', possibly of Arabic origin.

content.meaning_en: Mountain climbing, especially in the Alps or other high mountains.
usage_sentences: Modern alpinism requires both technical skill and extreme physical endurance.
He wrote a book about his experiences with alpinism in the Himalayas.
content.origin: From 'Alpine', relating to the Alps mountain range.

content.meaning_en: A table or flat-topped block used as the focus for a religious ritual.
usage_sentences: The priest stood before the altar to begin the service.
They placed flowers on the altar as an offering.

content.meaning_en: An instrument for determining altitude attained, especially one in an aircraft.
usage_sentences: The pilot checked the altimeter to ensure the plane was at the correct cruising altitude.
Hikers sometimes use a wrist altimeter to track their ascent.

content.meaning_en: A person unselfishly concerned for or devoted to the welfare of others.
usage_sentences: A true altruist, she dedicated her life to helping the poor and homeless.
The award was given to a local altruist for her community service.

content.meaning_en: A former student of a particular school, college, or university (male or gender-neutral singular).
usage_sentences: He is a proud alumnus of his university and attends all the homecoming games.
The famous author was invited back to speak as a distinguished alumnus.

content.meaning_en: A person who engages in a pursuit on an unpaid basis; for pleasure rather than as a profession.
usage_sentences: The photography competition was open to both professional and amateur photographers.
He is an amateur astronomer who loves stargazing from his backyard.
content.origin: From French, from Latin 'amator' (lover), from 'amare' (to love).

content.meaning_en: An abnormal or irrational fear of being in or riding in a vehicle.
content.meaning_hi: वाहन चलाने या उसमें बैठने का डर
usage_sentences: Her amaxophobia was so severe that she relied solely on walking and public transport.
Therapy can help people manage their amaxophobia and regain their independence.
content.note: Suffix '-phobia' denotes an extreme or irrational fear.

content.meaning_en: Able to use the right and left hands equally well.
usage_sentences: The ambidextrous artist could paint with either hand, often at the same time.
Being ambidextrous is a great advantage for a switch-hitter in baseball.

content.meaning_en: The character and atmosphere of a place.
usage_sentences: The cafe had a warm and welcoming ambience with soft lighting and comfortable chairs.
The music and decor created a perfect romantic ambience for the dinner.

content.meaning_en: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning; unclear.
usage_sentences: The instructions were ambiguous, and we weren't sure what to do next.
His reply to my question was frustratingly ambiguous.

content.meaning_en: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
usage_sentences: She was ambivalent about moving to a new city; she was excited for the opportunity but sad to leave her friends.
He had an ambivalent relationship with his brother, a mix of love and rivalry.

content.meaning_en: A person whose personality has a balance of extrovert and introvert features.
usage_sentences: As an ambivert, he enjoys socializing at parties but also values his alone time.
An ambivert can often adapt well to different social situations.
content.origin: From Latin 'ambi-' (both) + 'vertere' (to turn), patterned on 'extrovert' and 'introvert'.

content.meaning_en: To walk or move at a slow, relaxed pace.
usage_sentences: They decided to amble through the park on the sunny afternoon.
The old couple would amble along the seafront every evening.

content.meaning_en: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better; improve.
usage_sentences: The new policies were intended to ameliorate the poor working conditions.
A hot cup of tea can help to ameliorate the discomfort of a sore throat.

content.meaning_en: Open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded or controlled.
content.meaning_hi: सहमत होने वाला; सुझाव मानने वाला
usage_sentences: He was amenable to trying the new restaurant I suggested.
The students were amenable to the new classroom rules.
content.origin: From Old French 'amener', meaning 'to bring to'.

content.meaning_en: Having a spirit of friendliness; without serious disagreement.
usage_sentences: Despite the business dispute, they managed to reach an amicable settlement.
Their divorce was surprisingly amicable, with no arguments over custody.

content.meaning_en: A partial or total loss of memory.
usage_sentences: After the car crash, the driver suffered from temporary amnesia.
In the movie, the main character wakes up with amnesia and has to rediscover his identity.

content.meaning_en: An official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offences.
usage_sentences: The new government granted an amnesty to all political prisoners.
The library offered an amnesty period where people could return overdue books without a fine.

content.meaning_en: A person who has had a limb amputated.
usage_sentences: The charity provides prosthetic limbs for child amputees in war-torn countries.
After the accident, he became a double amputee but continued to live a full life.
content.origin: From 'amputate', derived from Latin 'amputare' (to cut around).

content.meaning_en: A word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase.
usage_sentences: The word 'listen' is an anagram of 'silent'.
She enjoyed solving anagram puzzles in the daily newspaper.

content.meaning_en: The inability to feel pain while still conscious.
usage_sentences: The medication provided effective analgesia for several hours after the surgery.
Acupuncture is sometimes used to induce a state of analgesia.

content.meaning_en: A comparison between two things, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification.
usage_sentences: The teacher used the analogy of a camera to explain how the human eye works.
He drew an analogy between the company's structure and a beehive.

content.meaning_en: A person who believes in or tries to bring about anarchy (a state of disorder).
usage_sentences: The political philosopher identified as an anarchist, advocating for a society without rulers.
A small group of anarchists organized the protest against the government.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: The branch of science concerned with the bodily structure of living organisms.
usage_sentences: In their first year, medical students must take a course in human anatomy.
The book contains detailed illustrations of the anatomy of a frog.

content.meaning_en: A short, amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
usage_sentences: The professor often shared a personal anecdote to illustrate a point in his lecture.
Her travel blog is filled with humorous anecdotes about her adventures.

content.meaning_en: A medical specialist who administers anesthetics.
usage_sentences: The anesthetist carefully monitored the patient's breathing during the long operation.
Before the surgery, the anesthetist explained the procedure for the anesthesia.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or resembling a weak, foolish old woman.
content.meaning_hi: बूढ़ी औरत जैसा; कमजोर और मूर्ख
usage_sentences: He dismissed her concerns with an anile comment about her age.
The character in the play was an anile figure, constantly worrying over trivial matters.

content.meaning_en: Strong hostility or dislike.
usage_sentences: There was a great deal of animosity between the two competing teams.
He felt no animosity towards the people who had wronged him.

content.meaning_en: To destroy utterly; obliterate.
content.meaning_hi: पूरी तरह नष्ट कर देना; विनाश करना
usage_sentences: The goal of the video game is to annihilate the alien invaders.
A nuclear weapon has the power to annihilate an entire city.

content.meaning_en: A fixed sum of money paid to someone each year, typically for the rest of their life.
usage_sentences: He invested in an annuity to ensure a steady income during his retirement.
Her grandfather left her a small annuity in his will.

content.meaning_en: Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
usage_sentences: The scientists were puzzled by the anomaly in the data from their experiment.
A bird that cannot fly is an anomaly in the avian world.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person) not identified by name; of unknown name.
usage_sentences: The hospital received a large anonymous donation.
The author of the controversial book chose to remain anonymous.

content.meaning_en: An emotional disorder characterized by an obsessive desire to lose weight by refusing to eat.
usage_sentences: She was hospitalized for severe anorexia and malnutrition.
Anorexia nervosa is a serious mental health condition that requires professional help.

content.meaning_en: A published collection of poems or other pieces of writing or music.
usage_sentences: The professor compiled an anthology of short stories by famous authors.
This anthology features the work of several new and emerging poets.
content.origin: From Greek 'anthologia', meaning 'a collection of flowers'.

content.meaning_en: An expert in the study of human societies and cultures and their development.
usage_sentences: The anthropologist spent years living with a remote tribe to study their way of life.
A cultural anthropologist can provide insights into different social customs.

content.meaning_en: To regard as probable; expect or predict; look forward to.
usage_sentences: We anticipate a large crowd at the concert, so we've arranged extra security.
She was eagerly anticipating her summer vacation.

content.meaning_en: A medicine taken or given to counteract a particular poison.
usage_sentences: The hospital quickly administered the antidote after the snakebite.
There is no known antidote for that particular chemical poison.

content.meaning_en: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
usage_sentences: He felt a strong antipathy towards his arrogant new boss.
There has been a long-standing antipathy between the two nations.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or dealing in antiques or rare books; a person who studies or collects antiques.
content.meaning_hi: पुरावस्तु विशेषज्ञ; पुरातन वस्तुओं से सम्बंधित
usage_sentences: The antiquarian book fair attracted collectors from all over the world.
As an antiquarian, he had a vast knowledge of historical artifacts.

content.meaning_en: A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
usage_sentences: Her calm and quiet demeanor was the antithesis of her brother's loud personality.
Slavery is the antithesis of freedom.

content.meaning_en: A policy or system of segregation or discrimination on grounds of race.
usage_sentences: Nelson Mandela was a key figure in the fight to end apartheid in South Africa.
The system of apartheid created deep social and economic divisions.

content.meaning_en: A suite of rooms forming one residence, typically in a building containing a number of these.
usage_sentences: They moved into a two-bedroom apartment in the city center.
The apartment building has a gym and a swimming pool for residents.

content.meaning_en: Showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
usage_sentences: The low voter turnout suggested that many citizens were apathetic about the election.
He had become apathetic and withdrawn after losing his job.

content.meaning_en: Loss of ability to understand or express speech, caused by brain damage.
usage_sentences: After his stroke, he suffered from aphasia and had to relearn how to speak.
Speech therapy can help patients with aphasia to improve their communication skills.

content.meaning_en: A place where bees are kept; a collection of beehives.
usage_sentences: The beekeeper collected fresh honey from the hives in his apiary.
An apiary was established in the orchard to help pollinate the fruit trees.

content.meaning_en: An event involving destruction or damage on an awesome or catastrophic scale.
usage_sentences: Many blockbuster movies depict a future world struggling after an apocalypse.
The environmentalist warned of an ecological apocalypse if climate change is not addressed.

content.meaning_en: The point in an orbit furthest from the earth; the highest point or climax.
usage_sentences: The satellite reached its apogee at a distance of 40,000 kilometers from Earth.
His career reached its apogee when he won the championship.

content.meaning_en: The abandonment or renunciation of a religious or political belief.
usage_sentences: In some societies, apostasy is considered a serious crime.
His public declaration against his former party was seen as an act of political apostasy.
content.origin: From Greek 'apostasia', meaning 'a standing away from'.

content.meaning_en: A person who renounces a religious or political belief or principle.
usage_sentences: He was condemned as an apostate by his former religious community.
The former party loyalist was now considered an apostate for his change of views.

content.meaning_en: Each of the twelve chief disciples of Jesus Christ; a vigorous and pioneering advocate of a cause.
content.meaning_hi: ईसा का शिष्य; धर्म प्रचारक; अग्रणी समर्थक
usage_sentences: Saint Peter is considered one of the most important apostles in Christianity.
She was a true apostle of modern art, promoting new artists.

content.meaning_en: Causing shock or dismay; horrific; very bad.
usage_sentences: The living conditions in the refugee camp were appalling.
His behavior at the party was appalling and rude.
content.origin: From Old French 'apalir', meaning 'to grow pale'.

content.meaning_en: Attractive or interesting.
usage_sentences: The idea of a vacation on a tropical island is very appealing.
The marketing team tried to make the product more appealing to younger customers.
content.origin: From the verb 'appeal', from Latin 'appellare' (to address).

content.meaning_en: Make a serious or urgent request; be attractive or interesting; apply to a higher court.
content.meaning_hi: अनुरोध करना; आकर्षक लगना; अपील करना
usage_sentences: The charity made an appeal for donations to help the victims of the flood.
He decided to appeal the court's decision.
content.origin: From Latin 'appellare', meaning 'to address, to call upon'.

content.meaning_en: Relate to; concern; be appropriate or applicable.
usage_sentences: The legal documents appertaining to the sale of the house were signed yesterday.
He was asked to handle all matters that appertain to the new project.
content.origin: From Old French 'apartenir', from Latin 'ad-' (to) + 'pertinere' (to belong).

content.meaning_en: An act of assessing something or someone; an expert estimate of the value of something.
usage_sentences: She received a positive performance appraisal from her manager at the end of the year.
We need to get an official appraisal of the property's value before we sell it.

content.meaning_en: To recognize the full worth of; understand a situation fully; rise in value.
usage_sentences: I truly appreciate all the help you've given me.
The value of their house has appreciated significantly over the last few years.

content.meaning_en: A person who is learning a trade from a skilled employer for a fixed period.
usage_sentences: He began his career as an apprentice to a master carpenter.
The young apprentice watched carefully to learn the craft.

content.meaning_en: (Of land) used or suitable for growing crops.
usage_sentences: The valley has rich, arable land that is perfect for farming.
Only a small percentage of the country's land is arable.

content.meaning_en: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
usage_sentences: The selection of the winner seemed completely arbitrary.
The dictator was known for his arbitrary use of power.

content.meaning_en: An independent person or body officially appointed to settle a dispute.
usage_sentences: An arbitrator was called in to resolve the contract dispute between the company and the union.
The decision of the arbitrator is legally binding.

content.meaning_en: (Chiefly of animals) living in trees; relating to trees.
usage_sentences: Monkeys and koalas are well-known arboreal animals.
The sloth's long claws are an adaptation for its arboreal lifestyle.

content.meaning_en: Very old or old-fashioned; no longer in everyday use.
usage_sentences: The use of 'thee' and 'thou' is considered archaic in modern English.
The museum displayed archaic tools from a bygone era.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: A person who studies human history through the excavation of sites and analysis of artifacts.
usage_sentences: The archeologist carefully brushed away dirt from the ancient fossil.
A team of archeologists discovered the ruins of a lost city.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: A group or chain of islands.
usage_sentences: The Philippines is a large archipelago made up of over 7,000 islands.
They went island-hopping across the Greek archipelago.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: A collection of historical documents or records; the place where these are stored.
usage_sentences: The historian spent months researching in the national archives.
The town's archives contain records dating back to the 18th century.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: Great enthusiasm or passion; intense feeling.
usage_sentences: He pursued his dream of becoming a musician with great ardour.
She spoke with ardour about the need for social justice.

content.meaning_en: A level area surrounded by seating, in which sports or other public events are held.
usage_sentences: The famous band played a concert in a sold-out sports arena.
The political arena can be a very competitive place.
content.origin: From Latin 'harena', meaning 'sand, sandy place' (as ancient arenas were covered in sand).

content.meaning_en: The highest class in certain societies, especially those holding hereditary titles or offices.
usage_sentences: The novel is set among the British aristocracy in the 19th century.
Many revolutions have aimed to overthrow the ruling aristocracy.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: A fleet of warships.
usage_sentences: The most famous naval fleet in history is the Spanish Armada of 1588.
The country sent an armada to defend its coastal waters.

content.meaning_en: An agreement made by opposing sides in a war to stop fighting for a certain time; a truce.
usage_sentences: The two warring nations finally agreed to an armistice.
Armistice Day is celebrated to mark the end of World War I.

content.meaning_en: A collection of weapons and military equipment stored by a country, person, or group.
usage_sentences: The country's nuclear arsenal was a major topic of international discussion.
The police raided the building and discovered an arsenal of illegal weapons.
content.origin: From Arabic 'dār aṣ-ṣinā'a', meaning 'house of manufacture'.

content.meaning_en: The criminal act of deliberately setting fire to property.
usage_sentences: He was sentenced to ten years in prison for committing arson.
The fire was determined to be an act of arson.
content.origin: From Old French 'arson', from Latin 'ardere' (to burn).

content.meaning_en: A person who commits arson.
usage_sentences: The police are still searching for the arsonist who set the warehouse on fire.
An arsonist poses a great danger to the community.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
usage_sentences: She is an articulate speaker who can explain complex ideas clearly.
It's important to be able to articulate your thoughts during a job interview.

content.meaning_en: A person who practices severe self-discipline and abstention from indulgence.
usage_sentences: The monk lived an ascetic life of prayer and fasting.
He followed an ascetic diet, eating only simple foods.

content.meaning_en: To attribute something to (a cause, person, etc.); give credit to.
usage_sentences: The doctor ascribed his patient's recovery to the new medication.
She was quick to ascribe her success to the support of her team.

content.meaning_en: With an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval.
content.meaning_hi: संदेह या अविश्वास से; तिरछी नज़र से
usage_sentences: The villagers looked askance at the stranger who had just arrived in town.
She looked askance at his proposal, doubting its sincerity.
content.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from Middle English.

content.meaning_en: A person who physically attacks another.
usage_sentences: The victim provided a detailed description of her assailant to the police.
He bravely fought off his assailant and escaped.

content.meaning_en: A person who murders an important person for political or religious reasons.
usage_sentences: The president was killed by a lone assassin.
A secret plot to hire an assassin was uncovered by the intelligence agency.
content.origin: From Arabic 'ḥašīšī', meaning 'hashish-eater', a term for a member of a secret order.

content.meaning_en: The expression of approval or agreement.
usage_sentences: The board of directors gave their assent to the new business plan.
She nodded her head in assent.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing a confident and forceful personality.
content.meaning_hi: दृढ़तापूर्वक अपनी बात कहने वाला; आग्रही
usage_sentences: You need to be more assertive in meetings if you want your ideas to be heard.
Her assertive communication style made her an effective leader.
content.origin: From the verb 'assert', from Latin 'asserere' (to claim).

content.meaning_en: The protection granted by a nation to someone who has left their native country as a political refugee.
usage_sentences: The activist sought political asylum in Canada to escape persecution.
Historically, the term asylum also referred to an institution for the mentally ill.

content.meaning_en: A person who disbelieves or lacks belief in the existence of God or gods.
usage_sentences: As an atheist, he based his morality on reason and humanism rather than divine command.
The debate between the priest and the atheist was watched by many.

content.meaning_en: Reparation or expiation for wrong or injury; making amends.
usage_sentences: He worked in the community as an act of atonement for his past crimes.
The story is about a man's search for atonement and forgiveness.
content.origin: From the phrase 'at one', meaning to be in harmony.

content.meaning_en: A space or room just below the roof of a building.
usage_sentences: They cleared out the dusty attic and converted it into a playroom.
We store our old Christmas decorations in the attic.
content.origin: From 'Attic', relating to Attica in Greece, referring to a style of architectural column.

content.meaning_en: Goodbye until we meet again.
usage_sentences: Instead of saying goodbye, she smiled and said, 'Au revoir!'
'Au revoir, my friend. I hope to see you soon.'

content.meaning_en: An official inspection of an organization's accounts.
usage_sentences: The company has to prepare its financial records for the annual audit.
An independent firm was hired to conduct an audit of the charity's finances.
content.origin: From Latin 'auditus', from 'audire' (to hear), as accounts were originally read aloud.

content.meaning_en: The part of a building in which the audience sits; a large hall for public gatherings.
usage_sentences: The school play was performed in the main auditorium.
The speaker's voice echoed throughout the large auditorium.

content.meaning_en: Severe or strict in manner or appearance; (of living conditions) having no comforts or luxuries.
usage_sentences: The headmaster was an austere man who rarely smiled.
They lived an austere life in the monastery, with few possessions.

content.meaning_en: A system of government by one person with absolute power.
usage_sentences: The people rebelled against the ruler's oppressive autocracy.
In an autocracy, there are no checks and balances on the leader's power.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: The right or condition of self-government; freedom from external control.
usage_sentences: The region was granted greater autonomy to manage its own affairs.
As teenagers grow, they seek more autonomy from their parents.

content.meaning_en: An extreme or irrational fear of being alone or isolated.
usage_sentences: His autophobia made it difficult for him to stay at home by himself.
She experienced panic attacks due to her severe autophobia.
content.note: Suffix '-phobia' denotes an extreme or irrational fear.

content.meaning_en: A post-mortem examination to discover the cause of death.
usage_sentences: The coroner ordered an autopsy to determine how the person had died.
The results of the autopsy were crucial for the police investigation.

content.meaning_en: A mass of snow, ice, and rocks falling rapidly down a mountainside.
usage_sentences: The ski patrol warned of a high risk of an avalanche after the heavy snowfall.
The entire village was buried under a massive avalanche.
content.origin: From French, of Alpine dialect origin.

content.meaning_en: New and experimental ideas and methods in art, music, or literature.
usage_sentences: The art gallery is known for showcasing avant-garde artists.
His music was considered too avant-garde for mainstream audiences at the time.

content.meaning_en: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
usage_sentences: The classic tale warns against the destructive power of avarice.
His avarice led him to betray his friends for financial gain.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing an extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
usage_sentences: The avaricious king imposed heavy taxes on his poor subjects.
He was an avaricious man who was never satisfied with what he had.

content.meaning_en: A large cage, building, or enclosure for keeping birds in.
usage_sentences: The zoo built a new walk-through aviary for its tropical birds.
He kept a small aviary in his backyard for his canaries.

content.meaning_en: The killing of birds.
usage_sentences: The widespread use of certain pesticides unintentionally led to avicide.
Conservation groups protested against the acts of avicide near the sanctuary.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).

content.meaning_en: Having or showing a keen interest in or enthusiasm for something.
usage_sentences: She is an avid reader who finishes several books a week.
He is an avid supporter of his local football team.

content.meaning_en: Extreme eagerness or enthusiasm.
usage_sentences: She read the latest news about the discovery with great avidity.
He showed a surprising avidity for learning the new software.

content.meaning_en: A statement or proposition which is regarded as being established, accepted, or self-evidently true.
usage_sentences: In geometry, a basic axiom is that the shortest distance between two points is a straight line.
It is a widely accepted axiom that 'actions speak louder than words'.
content.origin: From Greek 'axiōma', meaning 'what is thought worthy or fit'.

content.meaning_en: Senseless talk or writing; nonsense.
usage_sentences: The politician's speech was dismissed by critics as pure balderdash.
He waved his hand and said, 'Don't listen to him, it's all balderdash!'
content.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly a jumble of words like 'balder' and 'dash'.

content.meaning_en: A large wrapped or bound bundle of paper, hay, or cotton for storage or transport.
usage_sentences: The farmer used a tractor to move the large bale of hay into the barn.
The recycling plant processes thousands of bales of cardboard each day.
content.origin: From Old French, of Germanic origin, related to 'ball'.

content.meaning_en: A poem or song narrating a story in short stanzas.
usage_sentences: The folk singer performed a haunting ballad about a lost love.
Many ancient ballads were passed down orally for generations before being written down.
content.origin: From Old French 'balade', from Latin 'ballare' (to dance).

content.meaning_en: Passing on or discussing (an idea or rumour) in a casual or uninformed way.
usage_sentences: The employees were bandying about rumors of a possible merger.
It's not professional to be bandying names about without any facts.
content.origin: From the verb 'bandy', possibly from French 'bander' (to rally).

content.meaning_en: The playful and friendly exchange of teasing remarks.
usage_sentences: The friends engaged in lighthearted banter throughout the evening.
There's always a lot of cheerful banter in the office on Fridays.

content.meaning_en: The sharp explosive cry of a dog; the tough protective outer sheath of a tree.
usage_sentences: The dog's loud bark woke up the entire neighborhood.
The artist used the rough texture of the tree's bark in her sculpture.
content.origin: From Old English 'beorcan' (to bark) and 'barc' (tree bark).

content.meaning_en: A large farm building used for storing grain, hay, or for housing livestock.
usage_sentences: The farmer stored the season's harvest of hay in the big red barn.
They held a wedding reception in a beautifully decorated old barn.

content.meaning_en: Lie exposed to warmth and light for relaxation and pleasure; revel in something pleasing.
usage_sentences: The cat loved to bask in the warm patch of sunlight by the window.
After winning the award, she took a moment to bask in the applause.
content.origin: From Old Norse 'baðask', meaning 'to bathe oneself'.

content.meaning_en: A device containing cells that convert chemical energy into electricity; the crime of striking someone.
usage_sentences: I need to replace the battery in my remote control.
He was charged with assault and battery after the fight.

content.meaning_en: Something enormous, especially a large and powerful organization or creature.
usage_sentences: The small family-owned shop couldn't compete with the retail behemoth.
The new cruise ship was a behemoth, towering over the other vessels in the port.
content.origin: From Hebrew 'bĕhēmōth', used in the Bible to describe a large creature.

content.meaning_en: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
usage_sentences: The politician's bellicose speech raised fears of an impending war.
He had a bellicose personality and was always looking for an argument.

content.meaning_en: Emit a deep loud roar, typically in pain or anger.
usage_sentences: The angry bull began to bellow and paw at the ground.
He would bellow at the television when his favorite team was losing.

content.meaning_en: Deprived of or lacking something; lonely and abandoned, especially through death.
usage_sentences: After the fire, the family was bereft of all their worldly possessions.
He felt completely bereft after his wife's passing.
content.origin: Past participle of the old verb 'bereave', from Old English 'berēafian'.

content.meaning_en: Any type of drink except water.
usage_sentences: The restaurant offers a wide variety of hot and cold beverages.
His favorite morning beverage is a strong cup of coffee.

content.meaning_en: A large group of people or things of a particular kind, especially women or birds.
usage_sentences: A bevy of reporters surrounded the celebrity as he left the courthouse.
We saw a bevy of quail scurrying across the path.

content.meaning_en: A person who is unreasonably attached to a belief, opinion, or faction and is prejudiced against others.
usage_sentences: It is difficult to have a rational conversation with a bigot.
He was a religious bigot who was intolerant of anyone with different beliefs.

content.meaning_en: An examination of tissue removed from a living body to discover the presence, cause, or extent of a disease.
usage_sentences: The doctor performed a biopsy on the suspicious mole to check for cancer.
The results of the biopsy will be available in a few days.

content.meaning_en: (Of a place) lacking vegetation and exposed; (of a situation) not hopeful or encouraging.
usage_sentences: The windswept landscape of the tundra is a bleak and desolate place.
After the factory closed, the town's future looked bleak.

content.meaning_en: The characteristic wavering cry of a sheep, goat, or calf.
usage_sentences: We could hear the faint bleat of a lost lamb from across the field.
The goats would bleat loudly whenever they were hungry.
content.origin: From Old English 'blǣtan', of imitative origin.

content.meaning_en: An intellectual or literary woman (often used dismissively in the past).
usage_sentences: In the 18th century, a woman who attended intellectual gatherings might be called a bluestocking.
The term 'bluestocking' was once used to mock educated women.
content.origin: Named after the Blue Stockings Society, an 18th-century English literary society.

content.meaning_en: A member of the Dutch and Huguenot population that settled in southern Africa.
usage_sentences: The Boer War was a significant conflict in South African history.
Many Boer farmers established large agricultural estates.

content.meaning_en: A socially unconventional person, especially one involved in the arts.
usage_sentences: The artist lived a bohemian lifestyle, rejecting societal norms and traditions.
The city's old quarter was a gathering place for writers, musicians, and other bohemians.
content.origin: From French 'bohémien' (gypsy), from the belief that Romani people came from Bohemia.

content.meaning_en: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated; pompous.
usage_sentences: The politician's bombastic speech was full of grand promises but lacked any real substance.
He is known for his bombastic writing style, which uses long and complicated words.
content.origin: From 'bombast', a type of cotton padding.

content.meaning_en: A large open-air fire used as part of a celebration or for burning trash.
usage_sentences: They gathered around the bonfire on the beach to sing songs and roast marshmallows.
A huge bonfire was lit to celebrate the festival.
content.origin: From 'bone' + 'fire', as animal bones were originally the main fuel.

content.meaning_en: An ornamental tree or shrub grown in a pot and artificially prevented from reaching its normal size.
usage_sentences: He has been cultivating a bonsai tree for over twenty years.
The art of bonsai requires great patience and attention to detail.

content.meaning_en: A curved flat piece of wood that returns to the thrower; an action that recoils on the originator.
usage_sentences: His plan to spread rumors backfired like a boomerang, damaging his own reputation.
The Australian Aborigines traditionally used the boomerang for hunting.
content.origin: From the language of the Dharug people of Australia.

content.meaning_en: Rough and bad-mannered; coarse; ill-mannered.
usage_sentences: Everyone was shocked by his boorish behavior at the formal dinner party.
It is boorish to interrupt someone while they are speaking.

content.meaning_en: A wide street in a town or city, typically one lined with trees.
usage_sentences: They took a leisurely stroll down the grand boulevard, admiring the architecture.
The city's main boulevard is famous for its luxury shops and cafes.
content.origin: From French, from a Dutch word meaning 'bulwark' or 'rampart'.

content.meaning_en: An attractively arranged bunch of flowers; the characteristic scent of a wine or perfume.
usage_sentences: He gave her a beautiful bouquet of red roses for their anniversary.
The wine had a complex bouquet of fruit and oak.

content.meaning_en: Belonging to or characteristic of the middle class, with reference to materialistic values.
usage_sentences: The novel satirized the comfortable, bourgeois lifestyle of the suburbs.
He criticized their bourgeois concern for social status and possessions.

content.meaning_en: A small shop selling fashionable clothes or accessories.
usage_sentences: She found a unique, handmade dress at a small boutique downtown.
The hotel was a chic boutique establishment with only ten rooms.

content.meaning_en: Relating to or affecting cattle; (of a person) sluggish, stupid, or dull.
usage_sentences: The farmer was an expert in bovine health.
He stared at me with a look of bovine incomprehension.

content.meaning_en: A pleasant shady place under trees or climbing plants in a garden or wood.
usage_sentences: They sat and talked in a secluded bower covered with roses.
The garden featured a leafy bower perfect for quiet reflection.

content.meaning_en: A place where beer is made commercially.
usage_sentences: We took a tour of the local craft brewery and sampled their different beers.
The old brewery building has now been converted into apartments.
content.origin: From the verb 'brew', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: The headgear used to control a horse; restrain; show resentment.
content.meaning_hi: लगाम; नियंत्रण में लाना; नाराज़गी दिखाना
usage_sentences: The rider carefully placed the bridle on the horse's head.
She bridled at the suggestion that she was not qualified for the job.
content.origin: From Old English 'brīdel', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A member of a gang that ambushes and robs people in forests and mountains.
usage_sentences: In old stories, travelers were often warned about brigands hiding in the mountain passes.
The wealthy merchant's caravan was attacked by a band of brigands.

content.meaning_en: A rich fabric, usually silk, woven with a raised pattern.
usage_sentences: The queen's magnificent gown was made of gold and silver brocade.
The antique chair was upholstered in a beautiful floral brocade.

content.meaning_en: A family of young animals produced at one time; to think deeply about something that makes one unhappy.
usage_sentences: The mother hen protected her brood of fluffy chicks.
He continued to brood over his failure long after the event.
content.origin: From Old English 'brōd', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A late morning meal eaten instead of breakfast and lunch.
usage_sentences: We decided to sleep in on Sunday and go out for a late brunch.
The cafe serves a popular weekend brunch menu.

content.meaning_en: A woman or girl with dark brown hair.
usage_sentences: The casting director was looking for a brunette to play the lead role.
My sister is a blonde, but I'm a brunette.

content.meaning_en: Gold or silver in bulk before coining, or valued by weight.
usage_sentences: The bank's vault contained millions of dollars worth of gold bullion.
Investors often buy gold bullion as a hedge against inflation.
content.origin: From Old French 'bouillon', meaning 'boiling', referring to a mint or melting house.

content.meaning_en: To confuse, perplex, or fluster.
usage_sentences: The complex legal document would bumfuzzle even the most experienced lawyer.
His contradictory statements completely bumfuzzled the jury.

content.meaning_en: To carry out a task clumsily or incompetently.
usage_sentences: He managed to bungle the simple task of making coffee.
The spies bungled the mission and had to abort.

content.meaning_en: An anchored float serving as a navigation mark; keep afloat or support.
usage_sentences: The ship carefully navigated around the red marker buoy.
The good news served to buoy his spirits.
content.origin: From Dutch 'boei' or Old French 'boie', meaning 'a float' or 'a fetter'.

content.meaning_en: A person who commits burglary (entering a building illegally to steal).
usage_sentences: The burglar was caught on camera breaking into the house.
A burglar alarm can deter potential thieves.

content.meaning_en: A hole or tunnel dug by a small animal as a dwelling; to dig.
usage_sentences: The rabbit disappeared down its burrow.
He had to burrow through the pile of paperwork on his desk.
content.origin: A variant of 'borough', from Old English 'burg' (fortified place).

content.meaning_en: A cowshed.
usage_sentences: The farmer milked the cows in the byre every morning at dawn.
The old stone byre was converted into a holiday cottage.

content.meaning_en: Entertainment held in a nightclub or restaurant while the audience eats or drinks.
usage_sentences: They went to a dinner theater that featured a lively cabaret show.
She was a famous cabaret singer in Paris in the 1920s.

content.meaning_en: A collection of items stored in a hidden place; an auxiliary computer memory.
usage_sentences: The squirrels had a cache of nuts hidden for the winter.
Clearing your browser's cache can sometimes improve its performance.

content.meaning_en: A person who is bad at spelling or writing.
usage_sentences: His emails were hard to read because he was a notorious cacographer.
Even with spell-check, a cacographer can still make many errors.

content.meaning_en: Resembling a corpse in being very pale, thin, or bony.
content.meaning_hi: शव जैसा; अत्यंत पीला और दुबला
usage_sentences: After his long illness, he looked gaunt and cadaverous.
The old man's face was cadaverous and pale.

content.meaning_en: A modulation or inflection of the voice; rhythm.
usage_sentences: He spoke in the slow, rhythmic cadence of a seasoned storyteller.
The gentle cadence of the rain on the roof was very soothing.

content.meaning_en: Showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
usage_sentences: The manager's callous disregard for his employees' well-being was shocking.
It was a callous act to fire him just before the holidays.

content.meaning_en: The disguising of military personnel or equipment by blending in with the surroundings.
usage_sentences: The soldiers wore camouflage uniforms to blend in with the jungle.
The chameleon's ability to change color is a natural form of camouflage.

content.meaning_en: Love of dogs.
usage_sentences: Her canophilia is evident from the five rescue dogs she lives with.
The festival was a celebration of canophilia, with events for dogs and their owners.

content.meaning_en: (Of a boat) overturn in the water.
usage_sentences: A sudden gust of wind caused the small sailboat to capsize.
The crew managed to survive after their canoe capsized in the rapids.
content.origin: Possibly from Spanish 'capuzar', meaning 'to sink by the head'.

content.meaning_en: A group of people (traders, pilgrims) travelling together across a desert; a vehicle equipped for living in.
usage_sentences: In ancient times, a camel caravan was the only way to cross the vast desert.
They spent their summer holiday travelling through the country in a caravan.

content.meaning_en: The dead body of an animal.
usage_sentences: Vultures and other scavengers quickly gathered around the deer carcass.
The carcass was found by a group of hikers.

content.meaning_en: Of the greatest importance; fundamental; a leading dignitary of the Roman Catholic Church.
usage_sentences: The cardinal rule of the club is to treat everyone with respect.
The Pope met with the cardinals to discuss important church matters.

content.meaning_en: A picture or description exaggerating characteristics for comic effect.
usage_sentences: The street artist drew a humorous caricature of me with a very large nose.
The newspaper's political caricature often mocked the president.

content.meaning_en: The killing of a large number of people; massacre.
usage_sentences: The aftermath of the battle was a scene of utter carnage.
The documentary depicted the carnage of the civil war.

content.meaning_en: A religious folk song or popular hymn, especially for Christmas.
usage_sentences: A group of singers went from house to house singing Christmas carols.
My favorite carol is 'Silent Night'.
content.origin: From Old French 'carole', a kind of dance-song.

content.meaning_en: An association of manufacturers aiming to maintain high prices and restrict competition.
usage_sentences: The international oil cartel agreed to limit production to drive up prices.
Governments often have laws to prevent the formation of illegal cartels.

content.meaning_en: A person who draws or produces maps.
usage_sentences: A skilled cartographer created the detailed map for the explorers.
Before GPS, sailors relied heavily on the work of cartographers.

content.meaning_en: A small waterfall; to fall or flow downwards rapidly.
content.meaning_hi: छोटा झरना; झरने की तरह गिरना
