usage_sentences: His excuse for being late sounded plausible, but I wasn't completely convinced.
The police are investigating a number of plausible theories.

content.meaning_en: The direct vote of all members of an electorate on an important public question.
usage_sentences: The government held a plebiscite to decide whether to join the international treaty.
The results of the plebiscite showed overwhelming support for the proposal.

content.meaning_en: Government by the wealthy; a state or society governed by the wealthy.
usage_sentences: Critics argue that the country is becoming a plutocracy, where money equals political power.
In a plutocracy, the needs of the poor are often ignored.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: Evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret; touching.
usage_sentences: The photograph of the old man looking at his childhood home was deeply poignant.
It was a poignant reminder of how quickly time passes.
content.origin: From Old French, from 'poindre' (to prick, sting).

content.meaning_en: Relating to or involving strongly critical, controversial, or disputatious writing or speech.
usage_sentences: He wrote a polemical essay attacking the government's new policies.
The debate became polemical, with both sides refusing to compromise.

content.meaning_en: The practice or custom of having more than one husband at the same time.
usage_sentences: Polyandry is a rare form of marriage practiced in some Himalayan cultures.
The anthropologist studied the social structure of a community that practiced polyandry.

content.meaning_en: The practice or custom of having more than one wife or husband at the same time.
usage_sentences: Polygamy is illegal in many countries.
The documentary explored the lives of families in a culture that practices polygamy.

content.meaning_en: Knowing or using several languages.
usage_sentences: The tour guide was a polyglot who could switch effortlessly between English, French, and Spanish.
As a polyglot, she found it easy to find work in international relations.

content.meaning_en: Able to be easily carried or moved.
content.meaning_hi: वहनीय; आसानी से ले जाने योग्य
usage_sentences: He bought a small, portable speaker to take to the beach.
A laptop is a portable computer that you can use anywhere.

content.meaning_en: A range of investments; a set of pieces of creative work; the position and duties of a minister.
content.meaning_hi: निवेश सूची; कलाकृतियों का संग्रह; मंत्री पद
usage_sentences: The artist showed her portfolio to the gallery owner.
It is wise to have a diverse portfolio of investments.

content.meaning_en: A child born after the death of their father.
usage_sentences: The soldier's posthumous child was born two months after he died in battle.
The will made special provisions for any potential posthumous child.
content.origin: From 'posthumous', Latin 'postumus' (last, born after the father's death).

content.meaning_en: An additional remark at the end of a letter, after the signature (P.S.).
usage_sentences: She finished the letter but then added a postscript to say she had forgotten to mention something.
In his postscript, he wrote, 'P.S. I love you.'

content.meaning_en: A liquid mixture (often medicine, poison, or magic).
usage_sentences: In the fairytale, the witch brewed a magic potion that would make the princess fall asleep.
He drank the love potion and immediately fell for the first person he saw.

content.meaning_en: A mixture of dried petals and spices used to perfume a room; a varied mixture of things.
content.meaning_hi: सूखे फूलों का मिश्रण; विविध मिश्रण
usage_sentences: She kept a bowl of potpourri on the table to make the room smell nice.
The concert was a potpourri of different musical styles.

content.meaning_en: A person guided more by practical considerations than by ideals.
usage_sentences: While the idealist dreamed of a perfect world, the pragmatist focused on making small, practical improvements.
As a pragmatist, she chose the solution that was most likely to work, not the one that sounded best on paper.

content.meaning_en: An earlier event or action regarded as an example or guide in subsequent similar circumstances.
usage_sentences: The judge's ruling set a legal precedent for future cases of a similar nature.
There is no precedent for a situation like this.

content.meaning_en: A very steep rock face or cliff, typically a tall one.
usage_sentences: The car skidded and came to a stop just inches from the edge of the precipice.
The climbers carefully made their way up the steep precipice.

content.meaning_en: A person who held a job or office before the current holder.
usage_sentences: The new CEO implemented changes that were very different from his predecessor.
She inherited a difficult situation from her predecessor.

content.meaning_en: An introduction to a book, typically stating its subject, scope, or aims.
usage_sentences: In the preface, the author thanked everyone who had helped her with the book.
It's a good idea to read the preface to understand the author's intentions.

content.meaning_en: An action or event serving as an introduction to something more important.
usage_sentences: The small argument was a prelude to the major fight that followed.
The composer wrote a short prelude to begin the opera.

content.meaning_en: A strong feeling that something is about to happen, especially something unpleasant.
usage_sentences: She had a sudden premonition of danger and decided not to get on the plane.
He dismissed his feeling of unease as just a silly premonition.

content.meaning_en: Speak or act in an evasive way; avoid telling the truth by not directly answering a question.
usage_sentences: When asked about his involvement, the witness began to prevaricate and change his story.
Stop prevaricating and give me a straight answer.

content.meaning_en: Deep pleasure from achievements; consciousness of dignity; a group of lions.
usage_sentences: She took great pride in her children's accomplishments.
A pride of lions rested in the shade of the acacia tree.
content.origin: From Old English 'prȳde', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A person serving a probationary period in a job or position.
usage_sentences: As a probationer, her work was closely monitored for the first three months.
The new police recruits were probationers until they completed their training.

content.meaning_en: Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
usage_sentences: The prodigal son in the parable wasted his inheritance on a life of luxury.
He lived a prodigal lifestyle, spending money as if it would never run out.
content.origin: From late Latin 'prodigalis', from 'prodigere' (to drive away, waste).

content.meaning_en: A person, especially a young one, endowed with exceptional abilities or qualities.
usage_sentences: Mozart was a child prodigy who composed music from a very young age.
The young chess prodigy defeated several grandmasters.

content.meaning_en: Recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources; licentious.
usage_sentences: The profligate gambler lost his entire fortune at the casino.
The ancient Roman emperor was known for his profligate lifestyle.

content.meaning_en: Workers or working-class people, regarded collectively (often in Marxism).
usage_sentences: Karl Marx wrote about the inevitable conflict between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie.
The revolution was led by the proletariat, who sought to overthrow the ruling class.
content.origin: From French 'prolétariat', from Latin 'proletarius' (a person of the lowest class).

content.meaning_en: Rapid increase in numbers; rapid reproduction.
usage_sentences: The proliferation of nuclear weapons is a major global concern.
The internet has led to a proliferation of information, both good and bad.

content.meaning_en: A separate introductory section of a literary or musical work.
usage_sentences: The prologue of the novel sets the stage for the events that follow.
Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet' opens with a famous prologue.

content.meaning_en: Continuing for a long time or longer than usual; lengthy.
usage_sentences: A prolonged drought caused severe damage to the crops.
He had to take a prolonged absence from work due to his illness.
content.origin: From the verb 'prolong', from late Latin 'prolongare'.

content.meaning_en: Having or involving many transient sexual relationships; indiscriminate.
content.meaning_hi: अनेक व्यक्तियों से यौन संबंध रखने वाला
usage_sentences: He had a promiscuous lifestyle in his youth but later settled down.
The report criticized the promiscuous use of antibiotics.

content.meaning_en: A pole or beam used as support; an object used by actors; to support.
usage_sentences: He used a wooden prop to keep the heavy branch from falling.
The actor forgot his prop and had to improvise.
content.origin: Probably from a Middle Dutch word 'proppe' (support for a vine).

content.meaning_en: A person who advocates a theory, proposal, or course of action.
usage_sentences: She is a leading proponent of renewable energy.
He was a vocal proponent of the new tax reform.

content.meaning_en: Forbid, especially by law; denounce or condemn.
usage_sentences: The new law will proscribe the use of certain dangerous chemicals.
The organization was proscribed for its involvement in illegal activities.

content.meaning_en: Institute legal proceedings against (a person or organization).
usage_sentences: The district attorney decided to prosecute the suspect for robbery.
Shoplifters will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

content.meaning_en: A person who has converted from one opinion, religion, or party to another.
usage_sentences: He was a new proselyte, eager to learn about his new faith.
The missionaries tried to win new proselytes.

content.meaning_en: The leading character or one of the major characters in a play, film, novel, etc.
usage_sentences: The protagonist of the story is a young hero on a quest.
We are supposed to sympathize with the protagonist, even when she makes mistakes.

content.meaning_en: A first or preliminary version of a device or vehicle from which other forms are developed.
usage_sentences: The engineers are currently testing a working prototype of the new electric car.
The first prototype had several flaws that were corrected in later versions.

content.meaning_en: Animal fodder; food.
usage_sentences: The farmer stored hay and oats in the barn as provender for his horses.
The travelers carried enough provender for their long journey.
content.origin: From Old French 'provende', from late Latin 'praebenda' (a grant).

content.meaning_en: A person who moves stealthily around a place with a view to committing a crime.
content.meaning_hi: चोरी के इरादे से घूमने वाला
usage_sentences: The police arrested a prowler who was looking into the windows of houses.
She was scared when she saw the shadow of a prowler in her backyard.

content.meaning_en: A person who studies elections and voting statistics.
usage_sentences: The psephologist analyzed the polling data to predict the election outcome.
Psephologists study voting patterns to understand political trends.

content.meaning_en: A fictitious name, especially one used by an author.
usage_sentences: George Orwell was the pseudonym of the writer Eric Blair.
She wrote her detective novels under a pseudonym.

content.meaning_en: The period during which adolescents reach sexual maturity and become capable of reproduction.
usage_sentences: The onset of puberty typically occurs earlier for girls than for boys.
Adolescence begins with the start of puberty.

content.meaning_en: Showing great attention to detail or correct behaviour.
usage_sentences: He was a punctilious host who made sure every detail of the party was perfect.
She was punctilious about following the rules of grammar.

content.meaning_en: A person who gambles; (UK informal) a customer or client.
usage_sentences: The successful punter won a large sum of money on the horse race.
The shopkeeper knew all his regular punters by name.
content.origin: From 'punt', a term in a card game, from French 'ponte'.

content.meaning_en: (Of organic matter) decay or rot and produce a fetid smell.
usage_sentences: The meat will putrefy if it is left out of the refrigerator for too long.
A terrible smell came from the pile of putrefying garbage.

content.meaning_en: An obsessive desire to set fire to things.
usage_sentences: The arsonist was diagnosed with pyromania by a psychiatrist.
Pyromania is a dangerous impulse control disorder.

content.meaning_en: The art of making or displaying fireworks; a brilliant performance.
usage_sentences: The New Year's Eve celebration included a spectacular pyrotechnics display.
The guitarist's solo was a display of technical pyrotechnics.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person's voice) shake or tremble in speaking.
usage_sentences: Her voice began to quaver with emotion as she told the sad story.
He was so nervous that his voice had a slight quaver.

content.meaning_en: A main wing or tail feather of a bird; a pen made from such a feather.
usage_sentences: In the past, people wrote with a quill dipped in ink.
The bald eagle dropped a large quill as it flew overhead.

content.meaning_en: Recurring every five years; lasting for five years.
usage_sentences: The association holds a quinquennial conference for its members.
The government launched a new quinquennial development plan.

content.meaning_en: Extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
usage_sentences: He had a quixotic plan to end world hunger all by himself.
While admirable, her quest to save every stray animal was quixotic.
content.origin: From Don Quixote, the hero of a novel by Cervantes.

content.meaning_en: A person who tells anecdotes in a skilful and amusing way.
usage_sentences: My grandfather was a wonderful raconteur who could captivate any audience with his stories.
A good raconteur knows how to pace a story for maximum effect.

content.meaning_en: Relating to fundamental nature; advocating thorough political/social reform.
usage_sentences: The new government proposed radical changes to the tax system.
He was a political radical who called for a complete overthrow of the existing order.

content.meaning_en: (Of writing/speech) lengthy and confused; walking for pleasure.
usage_sentences: His speech was a long, rambling account of his life story.
They spent the weekend rambling through the beautiful countryside.

content.meaning_en: Complex or unwelcome consequences of an action or event.
usage_sentences: The decision to close the factory had serious ramifications for the entire town.
We need to consider all the possible ramifications before we proceed.

content.meaning_en: Characterized by bitterness or resentment.
usage_sentences: The political debate was rancorous, with both sides trading insults.
Their divorce was a long and rancorous process.

content.meaning_en: Aggressively greedy or grasping.
usage_sentences: The rapacious corporation was accused of exploiting its workers.
He had a rapacious appetite for wealth and power.

content.meaning_en: A partial refund to someone who has paid too much; a deduction or discount.
usage_sentences: The company offered a cash rebate to customers who bought the new product.
After sending in the form, I received a rebate check in the mail.

content.meaning_en: Say that one no longer holds an opinion or belief.
content.meaning_hi: अपनी बात से मुकर जाना; त्याग देना
usage_sentences: Under pressure from the authorities, the scientist was forced to recant his controversial theory.
The witness later recanted her testimony, saying she had lied.

content.meaning_en: Summarize and state again the main points of.
usage_sentences: At the end of his lecture, the professor recapitulated the key arguments.
To recapitulate, our main goal is to increase sales by 20 percent.
content.origin: From late Latin 'recapitulare', literally 'to restate by heads or chapters'.

content.meaning_en: An object or space used to contain something.
usage_sentences: Please place all recyclable materials in the designated receptacle.
A flower is a receptacle for nectar.

content.meaning_en: Respond to (a gesture or action) by making a corresponding one.
usage_sentences: She was disappointed that he did not reciprocate her feelings of love.
They invited us to dinner, so we must reciprocate and have them over to our house soon.

content.meaning_en: A person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people.
usage_sentences: The famous author became a recluse in his later years, refusing all interviews.
He lived as a recluse in a remote cabin in the woods.
content.origin: From Old French 'reclus', from Latin 'recludere' (to shut up).

content.meaning_en: Military observation of a region to locate an enemy or ascertain strategic features.
usage_sentences: A reconnaissance plane was sent to gather information about enemy positions.
The team conducted a thorough reconnaissance of the area before starting the mission.

content.meaning_en: Excessive bureaucracy or adherence to official rules and formalities.
usage_sentences: The project was delayed for months due to government red-tapism.
Entrepreneurs often complain about the red-tapism involved in starting a new business.
content.origin: From the red or pink tape formerly used to tie up official documents.

content.meaning_en: Not or no longer needed or useful; (of worker) no longer employed due to job non-existence.
usage_sentences: With the new software, many of our old manual processes have become redundant.
He was made redundant when the company downsized.

content.meaning_en: A general vote by the electorate on a single political question.
usage_sentences: The country held a referendum to decide whether to change its constitution.
The result of the referendum was very close.
content.origin: Latin, meaning 'thing to be brought back or referred'.

content.meaning_en: The emblems or insignia of royalty; distinctive clothing worn at formal ceremonies.
usage_sentences: The king appeared at the ceremony in his full royal regalia, including his crown and sceptre.
The university professors wore their academic regalia for the graduation.

content.meaning_en: An object surviving from an earlier time, especially one of historical or sentimental interest.
usage_sentences: The museum displayed ancient relics from the Roman Empire.
This old photograph is a precious family relic.

content.meaning_en: Place (a defendant) on bail or in custody, especially when a trial is adjourned.
usage_sentences: The judge decided to remand the suspect in custody until the next hearing.
He was on remand for six weeks before his trial began.

content.meaning_en: Accounts of past experiences remembered; the enjoyable recollection of past events.
usage_sentences: His book is a collection of charming reminiscences about his childhood.
The old friends spent the evening sharing reminiscences of their school days.

content.meaning_en: Money paid for work or a service.
usage_sentences: The job offers a competitive salary and an excellent remuneration package.
The remuneration for this position will be based on experience.

content.meaning_en: A performance or interpretation, especially of a dramatic role or piece of music.
usage_sentences: Her rendition of the classic song was both powerful and emotional.
The actor's rendition of Hamlet received critical acclaim.
content.origin: From medieval Latin 'rendere' (to give back, render).

content.meaning_en: A person who deserts and betrays an organization, country, or set of principles.
usage_sentences: He was declared a renegade for abandoning his post and joining the enemy.
The renegade agent sold government secrets to a foreign power.
content.origin: From Spanish 'renegado', from medieval Latin 'renegare' (to renounce).

content.meaning_en: Conversation characterized by quick, witty comments or replies.
usage_sentences: The two comedians were masters of witty repartee.
Their clever repartee kept the audience laughing.

content.meaning_en: The return of someone to their own country; the sending back of money.
usage_sentences: The government organized the repatriation of its citizens from the war-torn region.
The repatriation of profits is a key concern for multinational corporations.
content.origin: From 'repatriate', from late Latin 'repatriare' (to return to one's country).

content.meaning_en: An unintended consequence occurring some time after an event, especially an unwelcome one.
usage_sentences: The decision to raise interest rates had serious repercussions for the housing market.
He did not consider the possible repercussions of his actions.

content.meaning_en: Cancel or postpone the punishment of (someone); give relief from something unpleasant.
usage_sentences: The governor granted the condemned prisoner a last-minute reprieve.
The rainy weather provided a welcome reprieve from the summer heat.

content.meaning_en: Able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
content.meaning_hi: लचीला; कठिनाइयों से उबरने में सक्षम
usage_sentences: Children are often more resilient than adults in dealing with change.
The local economy has proven to be surprisingly resilient to the recession.

content.meaning_en: A short period of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant.
usage_sentences: The caregivers were grateful for the brief respite from their demanding duties.
There was no respite from the constant noise of the city.
content.origin: From Old French 'respit', from Latin 'respectus' (respect, consideration).

content.meaning_en: The restoration of something lost or stolen to its proper owner; recompense for injury or loss.
usage_sentences: The court ordered the thief to make full restitution to his victims.
The museum is working on the restitution of artworks stolen during the war.

content.meaning_en: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily; reserved.
usage_sentences: He was very reticent about his personal life and rarely spoke about his past.
She is a shy and reticent person who does not enjoy public speaking.

content.meaning_en: The action of looking back on or reviewing past events or situations.
usage_sentences: In retrospection, he realized that he should have made a different decision.
Her memoir was a journey of retrospection, exploring the key moments of her life.

content.meaning_en: Give new and improved form, structure, or appearance to.
usage_sentences: The company decided to revamp its outdated website.
They are planning to revamp the entire kitchen.

content.meaning_en: A signal sounded on a bugle or drum to wake personnel in armed forces.
usage_sentences: The soldiers were woken at 6 a.m. by the sound of reveille.
His day in the army began with reveille and ended with taps.

content.meaning_en: Enjoy oneself in a lively and noisy way; take great pleasure in.
usage_sentences: The fans continued to revel in their team's victory long after the game was over.
She reveled in the opportunity to showcase her talent.

content.meaning_en: Feeling or showing deep and solemn respect.
usage_sentences: They spoke in hushed, reverent tones inside the ancient temple.
He has a reverent attitude towards nature.

content.meaning_en: A state of being pleasantly lost in one's thoughts; a daydream.
usage_sentences: She was lost in a reverie and didn't hear the teacher call her name.
He was startled out of his reverie by the sound of the phone ringing.

content.meaning_en: Criticize in an abusive or angrily insulting manner.
usage_sentences: The politician was reviled by the public for his corrupt practices.
He was reviled as a traitor by his former colleagues.

content.meaning_en: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing; language designed to impress but lacking sincerity.
usage_sentences: The speech was full of powerful rhetoric that moved the audience.
The people were tired of the politician's empty rhetoric and wanted action.
content.origin: From Greek 'rhētorikē (tekhnē)', meaning '(art) of an orator'.

content.meaning_en: A medical specialist who deals with the nose and its diseases.
usage_sentences: He consulted a rhinologist for his chronic sinus problems.
The rhinologist performed surgery to correct a deviated septum.

content.meaning_en: A round building or room, especially one with a dome.
usage_sentences: The U.S. Capitol building is famous for its large central rotunda.
The main reading room of the library was a magnificent rotunda.

content.meaning_en: The physical remains of something that has been destroyed or decayed.
usage_sentences: They spent the day exploring the ancient ruins of a Roman city.
The castle was left in ruins after the war.

content.meaning_en: Deliberately destroy, damage, or obstruct (something), especially for political or military advantage.
usage_sentences: The striking workers were accused of trying to sabotage the factory's machinery.
He suspected his rival of trying to sabotage his project.
content.origin: From French 'saboter', from 'sabot' (a type of wooden shoe), referring to workers throwing shoes into machinery.

content.meaning_en: A person who tends to be disorganized and forgetful.
usage_sentences: She is such a scatterbrain that she's always losing her keys.
As a scatterbrain, I have to write everything down or I'll forget it.

content.meaning_en: Violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred.
usage_sentences: It is considered sacrilege to vandalize a place of worship.
To the devout fan, criticizing the legendary player was a form of sacrilege.

content.meaning_en: Deriving pleasure from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on others.
usage_sentences: The cruel villain took sadistic pleasure in his evil deeds.
He has a sadistic sense of humor and enjoys seeing others embarrassed.
content.origin: From the name of the Marquis de Sade, an 18th-century French writer.

content.meaning_en: A simultaneous discharge of artillery or firearms; a sudden burst.
content.meaning_hi: तोपों की सलामी; प्रश्नों की बौछार
usage_sentences: The battleship fired a salvo of its main guns.
The politician was met with a salvo of questions from the reporters.

content.meaning_en: A charitable or helpful person (from the parable of the Good Samaritan).
usage_sentences: A Good Samaritan stopped to help me change my flat tire.
She is a true Samaritan, always willing to help those in need.
content.origin: From the biblical parable of the Good Samaritan in the New Testament.

content.meaning_en: (Historically in the Soviet Union) the clandestine copying and distribution of banned literature.
usage_sentences: Dissident writers circulated their work through the samizdat system.
The book was first published as a samizdat in the author's home country.

content.meaning_en: An establishment for the medical treatment of people with chronic illnesses.
usage_sentences: In the past, patients with tuberculosis were sent to a sanatorium in the mountains.
The old sanatorium has now been converted into a luxury hotel.

content.meaning_en: The state or quality of being holy, sacred, or saintly.
usage_sentences: Many religions believe in the sanctity of human life.
The lawyer argued for the sanctity of the contract.

content.meaning_en: Involving or causing much bloodshed.
usage_sentences: The history of the revolution was a long and sanguinary one.
The battle was one of the most sanguinary in the country's history.

content.meaning_en: Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.
usage_sentences: Despite the bad news, he remained sanguine about the company's future.
She has a sanguine temperament and always looks on the bright side.
content.origin: From Latin 'sanguis' (blood), relating to the four humors of ancient medicine.

content.meaning_en: Tasting (good food or drink) and enjoying it to the full; enjoying an experience slowly.
usage_sentences: He closed his eyes, savouring the delicious taste of the chocolate.
She was savouring every moment of her last day of vacation.

content.meaning_en: A sheath for the blade of a sword or dagger.
usage_sentences: The knight drew his sword from its ornate scabbard.
He returned the dagger to its scabbard at his belt.
content.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'escauberc', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: Barely sufficient or adequate.
usage_sentences: He paid scant attention to the details of the report.
Food was scant during the long winter.

content.meaning_en: Search for and collect (anything usable) from discarded waste; (of animal) feed on carrion.
usage_sentences: Vultures are known to scavenge for food.
He would scavenge for spare parts in the junkyard.

content.meaning_en: An ornamented staff carried by rulers on ceremonial occasions as a symbol of sovereignty.
usage_sentences: The queen held the royal sceptre during her coronation.
The orb and sceptre are important symbols of the monarchy.

content.meaning_en: A person inclined to question or doubt accepted opinions.
usage_sentences: He was a skeptic who demanded proof before he would believe anything.
Even after seeing the evidence, she remained a skeptic.

content.meaning_en: An institution for educating children; a large group of fish or aquatic mammals.
usage_sentences: My daughter is excited to start school next year.
We saw a large school of dolphins swimming alongside the boat.
content.origin: From Greek 'skholē' (leisure, lecture) and Middle Dutch 'schole' (troop).

content.meaning_en: Sparkling or shining brightly; brilliantly and excitingly clever or skillful.
usage_sentences: She was a scintillating conversationalist who could talk about any subject.
The diamond gave off a scintillating light.

content.meaning_en: The number of points in a game; a group or set of twenty.
usage_sentences: The final score of the game was three to one.
The biblical phrase 'three score years and ten' means seventy years.

content.meaning_en: Give a loud, harsh, piercing cry.
usage_sentences: The car's tires let out a loud screech as it stopped suddenly.
She let out a screech of terror when she saw the spider.

content.meaning_en: Loud, harsh, and piercing (sound).
usage_sentences: The old door hinge made a screechy noise every time it was opened.
I can't stand her high-pitched, screechy voice.

content.meaning_en: A confused struggle or fight; (Am. Football) play from the line of scrimmage.
usage_sentences: A scrimmage broke out between the two teams over the controversial call.
The team practiced a few scrimmage plays before the game.

content.meaning_en: A small kitchen or room at the back of a house used for washing dishes.
usage_sentences: In the old mansion, the scullery was where all the dirty kitchen work was done.
She found the old pot in the back of the scullery.

content.meaning_en: Making or spreading scandalous claims about someone to damage their reputation.
usage_sentences: The tabloid newspaper published a scurrilous article full of lies.
He sued the magazine for making scurrilous allegations against him.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person or small animal) move hurriedly with short quick steps.
content.meaning_hi: तेज़ी से चलना; फुर्ती से भागना
usage_sentences: A mouse scurried across the kitchen floor.
The children scurried off to their rooms when they heard their father coming.

content.meaning_en: Promoting calm or inducing sleep; a drug taken for its calming or sleep-inducing effect.
usage_sentences: The doctor gave the anxious patient a mild sedative to help him relax.
Listening to calm music can have a sedative effect.

content.meaning_en: (Of a person or action) showing dedication and diligence; persistent.
usage_sentences: He was a sedulous student who spent hours in the library.
Her sedulous attention to detail made her an excellent editor.

content.meaning_en: A person who is from 70 to 79 years old.
usage_sentences: The sprightly septuagenarian still runs marathons.
My grandfather is a septuagenarian, but he's very active.

content.meaning_en: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
usage_sentences: Finding that rare book in a second-hand shop was a moment of pure serendipity.
Their meeting was a matter of serendipity; they were both in the right place at the right time.
content.origin: Coined by Horace Walpole from 'Serendip', a former name for Sri Lanka, from a Persian fairy tale.

content.meaning_en: Divide by cutting or slicing; put an end to (a connection or relationship).
usage_sentences: The accident was so severe that it threatened to sever his arm.
After the big argument, she decided to sever all ties with him.
content.origin: From Old French 'sevrer', from Latin 'separare' (to separate).

content.meaning_en: A long, narrow part forming the handle of a tool; a ray of light; a vertical passageway.
usage_sentences: A shaft of sunlight broke through the clouds.
The miners descended into the deep mine shaft.
content.origin: From Old English 'sceaft', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A close-fitting cover for the blade of a knife or sword.
usage_sentences: He returned the sword to its leather sheath.
The electrical wire is protected by a plastic sheath.
content.origin: From Old English 'scēath', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A large number of fish swimming together; an area of shallow water.
usage_sentences: A large shoal of tuna was spotted off the coast.
The ship had to navigate carefully to avoid the dangerous shoals.

content.meaning_en: Fragments of a bomb, shell, or other object thrown out by an explosion.
usage_sentences: The soldier was wounded in the leg by shrapnel from a grenade.
The bomb blast sent shrapnel flying in all directions.
content.origin: Named after Major General Henry Shrapnel, who invented an exploding shell.

content.meaning_en: An afternoon rest or nap, especially one taken in hot countries.
usage_sentences: In Spain, it is common for shops to close for a siesta in the afternoon.
He felt refreshed after taking a short siesta.

content.meaning_en: The dark shape and outline of someone or something visible against a lighter background.
usage_sentences: We could see the silhouette of the castle against the sunset.
The artist drew a beautiful silhouette portrait of her.
content.origin: Named after Étienne de Silhouette, a French finance minister.

content.meaning_en: A position requiring little or no work but giving the holder status or financial benefit.
usage_sentences: His job as a consultant was a sinecure that paid well for very little effort.
The position on the board of directors was a sinecure given to a family friend.
content.origin: From Latin '(beneficium) sine cura' (benefice without cure of souls).

content.meaning_en: Make or become slack (loose); reduce or decrease in speed, intensity, or activity.
usage_sentences: He had to slacken the rope to free the knot.
The pace of the race began to slacken after the first few laps.

content.meaning_en: Have saliva dripping copiously from the mouth; show excessive sentimentality.
usage_sentences: The big dog would slobber all over you when it got excited.
He slobbered over the new baby, making cooing noises.

content.meaning_en: Kill (someone) by covering their nose and mouth; extinguish (a fire) by covering it.
usage_sentences: He tried to smother the flames with a wet blanket.
She smothered her child with too much love and attention, never letting him be independent.

content.meaning_en: A person with an exaggerated respect for high social position who behaves condescendingly to others.
usage_sentences: He is a wine snob who looks down on anyone who drinks cheap wine.
She was accused of being a snob for refusing to talk to people she considered beneath her.
content.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from a slang term for a shoemaker.

content.meaning_en: Comfortable, warm, and cosy; fitting closely.
usage_sentences: The cabin was small but snug and warm with a fire burning in the hearth.
The jacket was a snug fit.
content.origin: Probably of Low German or Dutch origin.

content.meaning_en: A temporary stay.
usage_sentences: During his sojourn in the countryside, he wrote a collection of poems.
After a brief sojourn in Paris, they continued their journey through Europe.
content.origin: From Old French 'sojorner', from Latin 'sub-' (under) + 'diurnus' (of a day).

content.meaning_en: A grammatical mistake in speech or writing; a breach of good manners.
usage_sentences: Using a double negative is a common solecism in English.
It was a social solecism to ask such a personal question.

content.meaning_en: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself, especially by a character in a play.
usage_sentences: Hamlet's famous 'To be or not to be' speech is a soliloquy.
The play ended with a powerful soliloquy from the main character.

content.meaning_en: A person who walks about in their sleep; a sleepwalker.
usage_sentences: The clinic treats patients who are somnambulists.
It can be dangerous to wake a somnambulist suddenly.

content.meaning_en: A person who talks in their sleep.
usage_sentences: My roommate is a somniloquist, and I often hear him mumbling in the middle of the night.
Being a somniloquist is a common sleep disorder.

content.meaning_en: A poem of fourteen lines using any of a number of formal rhyme schemes.
usage_sentences: William Shakespeare is famous for his collection of 154 sonnets.
The students were asked to write a sonnet for their poetry class.
content.origin: From Italian 'sonetto', a diminutive of 'suono' (a sound).

content.meaning_en: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
usage_sentences: The monotonous drone of the lecturer's voice had a soporific effect on the audience.
A warm glass of milk can be a natural soporific.

content.meaning_en: The use of magic, especially black magic.
usage_sentences: In the fantasy novel, the evil wizard was a master of sorcery.
In ancient times, people accused of practicing sorcery were often persecuted.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one's sister.
usage_sentences: The detective investigated the shocking case of sororicide.
The play's tragic plot revolved around an act of sororicide.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).

content.meaning_en: A thing that is kept as a reminder of a person, place, or event.
usage_sentences: I bought a small model of the Eiffel Tower as a souvenir of my trip to Paris.
She kept the ticket stub as a souvenir of the concert.

content.meaning_en: A sudden involuntary muscular contraction or convulsive movement.
usage_sentences: He felt a sharp muscle spasm in his back after lifting the heavy box.
A sudden spasm of coughing shook his body.

content.meaning_en: The exploration and study of caves.
usage_sentences: Speleology is a fascinating hobby for adventurous people.
The team of scientists conducted research in speleology, mapping the underground cave system.

content.meaning_en: An unmarried woman, typically an older woman beyond the usual age for marriage (often dated).
usage_sentences: In Jane Austen's novels, many female characters fear the fate of becoming a spinster.
The term spinster is now considered outdated and is rarely used.
content.origin: From 'spin', as unmarried women in the past often did spinning.

content.meaning_en: Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated.
usage_sentences: The protest was marked by sporadic outbreaks of violence.
We have been getting sporadic rain showers all day.

content.meaning_en: Not being what it purports to be; false or fake.
usage_sentences: He was arrested for making spurious claims to the insurance company.
The expert confirmed that the painting was a spurious imitation.

content.meaning_en: A noisy quarrel about something petty or trivial.
usage_sentences: The siblings were always having a squabble over who got to use the computer.
It was a silly squabble that was quickly forgotten.

content.meaning_en: Walk or move unsteadily, as if about to fall; astonish or deeply shock.
usage_sentences: He managed to stagger to his feet after the heavy blow.
The sheer scale of the disaster is enough to stagger the imagination.

content.meaning_en: A sudden panicked rush of a large number of animals or people.
usage_sentences: The loud gunshot caused a stampede among the herd of buffalo.
There was a stampede for the exits when the fire alarm went off.

content.meaning_en: An upright bar, post, or frame forming a support or barrier.
usage_sentences: The cows were secured in their stalls by metal stanchions.
The crowd was held back by a rope supported by stanchions.

content.meaning_en: (Especially of a woman) attractively tall, graceful, and dignified.
usage_sentences: The actress was a statuesque woman with a commanding presence.
She had a statuesque beauty that reminded him of a Greek goddess.

content.meaning_en: A written law passed by a legislative body.
usage_sentences: The new statute prohibits smoking in all public buildings.
According to the statute, the crime is punishable by up to five years in prison.

content.meaning_en: A person employed to load and unload ships.
usage_sentences: The stevedores worked all night to unload the cargo from the large container ship.
He worked as a stevedore at the docks for over 30 years.

content.meaning_en: A person who hides on a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle to travel without paying.
usage_sentences: The ship's crew discovered a stowaway hiding in one of the lifeboats.
He became a stowaway on a cargo ship, hoping to start a new life in another country.

content.meaning_en: Kill (someone) by squeezing their throat; restrict blood supply to a part of the body.
usage_sentences: The autopsy revealed that the victim had been strangulated.
A tight bandage can strangulate a limb and cut off circulation.

content.meaning_en: A government headed by military chiefs.
usage_sentences: After the coup, the country was ruled by a stratocracy.
Ancient Sparta was an example of a stratocracy, where the military held great power.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: Seriously affected by an undesirable condition or unpleasant feeling.
usage_sentences: The famine-stricken region received international aid.
The grief-stricken family gathered for the funeral.

content.meaning_en: Angry or bitter disagreement over fundamental issues; conflict.
usage_sentences: The country was torn apart by years of civil strife.
Political strife and division weakened the nation.

content.meaning_en: Talking with continued involuntary repetition of sounds.
usage_sentences: He developed a stuttering problem after the traumatic accident.
Speech therapy can be very effective in treating stuttering.
content.origin: From the verb 'stutter', of Germanic origin, imitative.

content.meaning_en: Bring under domination or control, especially by conquest.
usage_sentences: The powerful empire sought to subjugate all the neighboring tribes.
He was determined not to be subjugated by his fears.

content.meaning_en: A writ ordering a person to attend a court.
content.meaning_hi: सम्मन; अदालत में हाज़िरी का आदेश
usage_sentences: The witness was issued a subpoena to testify in the trial.
Failure to comply with a subpoena can result in legal penalties.

content.meaning_en: Prepared to obey others unquestioningly; less important; subordinate.
usage_sentences: She was tired of being in a subservient role and decided to start her own business.
In the traditional household, the wife was expected to be subservient to her husband.

content.meaning_en: The action of maintaining or supporting oneself at a minimum level.
usage_sentences: Many people in the village live by subsistence farming, growing just enough food for their families.
He earned a bare subsistence wage, with no money for luxuries.
content.origin: From late Latin 'subsistentia', from 'subsistere' (to stand firm).

content.meaning_en: Plants having thick fleshy leaves or stems adapted to storing water.
usage_sentences: Cacti and aloe vera are well-known types of succulents.
Succulents are popular houseplants because they are easy to care for.

content.meaning_en: The right to vote in political elections.
usage_sentences: The suffragette movement fought for women's suffrage.
Universal suffrage means that all adult citizens have the right to vote.

content.meaning_en: A set of rooms designated for one person's use; a set of related things.
usage_sentences: They booked the honeymoon suite at the luxury hotel.
The software package includes a suite of productivity tools.

content.meaning_en: Splendid and expensive-looking; lavish.
usage_sentences: The royal wedding was a sumptuous affair, with a magnificent banquet.
She wore a sumptuous gown made of silk and velvet.

content.meaning_en: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others.
usage_sentences: The supercilious waiter looked down his nose at the customers.
He gave a supercilious smile when I asked a simple question.
content.origin: From Latin 'superciliosus', from 'supercilium' (eyebrow), which can be raised in an arrogant expression.

content.meaning_en: Ask or beg for something earnestly or humbly.
usage_sentences: The villagers had to supplicate the king for food during the famine.
In his prayer, he would supplicate for forgiveness and guidance.

content.meaning_en: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of; stealthy.
usage_sentences: She cast a surreptitious glance at her watch during the boring meeting.
They carried on a surreptitious affair for years.
content.origin: From Latin 'surrepticius', from 'subripere' (to snatch away secretly).

content.meaning_en: A person's final performance or activity before retirement or death.
usage_sentences: The retiring actor gave his swan song performance on the Broadway stage.
The album was the musician's swan song before he passed away.
content.origin: From the ancient belief that swans sing a beautiful song just before they die.

content.meaning_en: A large or dense group of insects; a large number of people or things.
usage_sentences: A swarm of bees flew out of the hive when it was disturbed.
Tourists began to swarm the small coastal town in the summer.
content.origin: From Old English 'swearm', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: An elaborate musical composition for full orchestra.
usage_sentences: Beethoven's Fifth Symphony is one of the most famous pieces of classical music.
We went to hear the city's symphony orchestra perform last night.

content.meaning_en: The building where a Jewish assembly meets for religious worship.
usage_sentences: The family attends services at their local synagogue every Saturday.
The synagogue is the center of the Jewish community.

content.meaning_en: Showing poor taste and quality; slightly sticky.
usage_sentences: The tourist shop was full of cheap and tacky souvenirs.
The paint was still slightly tacky to the touch.
content.origin: Origin uncertain, related to 'tack' (a small nail).

content.meaning_en: Of or connected with the sense of touch; perceptible by touch.
usage_sentences: The museum had a special tactile exhibit for visually impaired visitors.
Velvet has a very pleasant tactile quality.

content.meaning_en: Uncontrolled outbursts of anger and frustration, typically in a young child.
usage_sentences: The toddler threw a temper tantrum in the middle of the supermarket.
He is prone to childish tantrums when he doesn't get his way.

content.meaning_en: A hard calcified deposit on teeth; a harsh, fierce person.
usage_sentences: The dental hygienist scraped the tartar from his teeth.
He was a real tartar to work for, demanding perfection.

content.meaning_en: The saying of the same thing twice in different words, generally considered a fault of style.
usage_sentences: Saying 'a free gift' is a tautology, because all gifts are free.
The politician's speech was full of empty tautologies.

content.meaning_en: A person who practices taxidermy (preparing, stuffing, and mounting animal skins).
usage_sentences: The hunter took his prize deer to a taxidermist to have it mounted.
A skilled taxidermist can make a preserved animal look very lifelike.

content.meaning_en: The branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms.
usage_sentences: In biology, taxonomy is the system used to classify living organisms into groups.
Linnaean taxonomy is a hierarchical system developed by Carl Linnaeus.

content.meaning_en: A person who never drinks alcohol.
usage_sentences: As a teetotaller, he always ordered soft drinks at the bar.
She has been a teetotaller her entire life.
content.origin: From the 'T' in 'total', used to emphasize 'total abstinence'.

content.meaning_en: A violent windy storm.
usage_sentences: The small fishing boat was caught in a violent tempest and nearly sank.
Shakespeare's play 'The Tempest' begins with a storm at sea.

content.meaning_en: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; persistent; determined.
usage_sentences: She was a tenacious reporter who wouldn't give up until she had the full story.
The weed has a tenacious grip on the soil and is difficult to remove.

content.meaning_en: A harsh-tempered or overbearing woman; a shrew.
usage_sentences: In the old play, the main character was married to a nagging termagant.
The word 'termagant' is an old-fashioned and offensive term for a woman.
content.origin: From 'Termagant', the name of a fictitious deity in medieval morality plays.

content.meaning_en: A system of government in which priests rule in the name of God or a god.
usage_sentences: In a theocracy, religious law is the basis of the country's legal system.
Some ancient civilizations were theocracies ruled by a priest-king.
content.note: Suffixes like '-cracy' or '-archy' typically refer to forms of government or rule.

content.meaning_en: The study of the nature of God and religious belief.
usage_sentences: He went to a seminary to study theology and become a priest.
The book is a complex work of Christian theology.

content.meaning_en: A delusion causing a person to believe they are God or chosen by God.
usage_sentences: The cult leader's theomania led his followers to believe he was a divine being.
A person suffering from theomania may require psychiatric help.

content.meaning_en: Relating to the healing of disease; having a good effect on the body or mind.
usage_sentences: A hot bath can have a therapeutic effect on sore muscles.
For many people, gardening is a very therapeutic activity.
content.origin: From Greek 'therapeutikos', from 'therapeuein' (to minister to, treat).

content.meaning_en: Complete with regard to every detail; performed with great care and completeness.
usage_sentences: The police conducted a thorough search of the area.
She has a thorough understanding of the subject.

content.meaning_en: A road or path forming a route between two places; a main road.
usage_sentences: The town's main street is a busy thoroughfare for cars and pedestrians.
The new highway will create a major thoroughfare between the two cities.

content.meaning_en: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
usage_sentences: He launched into a furious tirade about the poor service he had received.
The manager's tirade against the lazy employees was heard throughout the office.

content.meaning_en: Holding or relating to a title without related duties or authority.
usage_sentences: The queen is the titular head of the Church of England, but the Archbishop has the real authority.
He held a titular position on the board but had no real power.

content.meaning_en: A young child who is just beginning to walk.
usage_sentences: The park has a special play area for toddlers.
Life becomes very busy when you have a toddler running around the house.
content.origin: From the verb 'toddle' (to walk with short, unsteady steps).

content.meaning_en: A strong and fast-moving stream of water; a sudden, violent outpouring.
usage_sentences: After the heavy rain, the small stream turned into a raging torrent.
He unleashed a torrent of abuse at the referee.

content.meaning_en: Full of twists and turns; excessively lengthy and complex.
usage_sentences: The car carefully navigated the tortuous mountain road.
The legal document was full of tortuous language that was difficult to understand.

content.meaning_en: Relating to a system of government that is centralized, dictatorial and requires complete subservience.
usage_sentences: In a totalitarian state, the government has complete control over every aspect of life.
The novel '1984' depicts a terrifying totalitarian society.

content.meaning_en: Free from disturbance; calm; peaceful.
usage_sentences: They spent a tranquil afternoon by the quiet lake.
The yoga class helped her feel calm and tranquil.

content.meaning_en: Beyond or above the range of normal or physical human experience.
usage_sentences: Listening to the beautiful music was a transcendent experience for her.
The artwork had a transcendent quality that seemed to go beyond the physical canvas.

content.meaning_en: A person who breaks a law or moral rule; an offender.
usage_sentences: In the story, the transgressor was punished for his sins.
The sign warned that all transgressors would be prosecuted.

content.meaning_en: Lasting only for a short time; impermanent; staying only a short time.
usage_sentences: The city has a large transient population of seasonal workers.
The feeling of happiness was transient and soon replaced by worry.

content.meaning_en: A semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals; a portable radio.
usage_sentences: The invention of the transistor revolutionized the electronics industry.
He listened to the news on his small transistor radio.

content.meaning_en: Not permanent; temporary; brief.
usage_sentences: Youth and beauty are transitory.
Life is transitory, so it's important to make the most of it.

content.meaning_en: (Of the soul) pass into a different body after death.
usage_sentences: Some religions have a belief in the transmigration of the soul, or reincarnation.
The ancient philosopher wrote about the transmigration of souls.

content.meaning_en: A surprising or magical transformation.
usage_sentences: The fairytale describes the transmogrification of a pumpkin into a carriage.
The sudden transmogrification of the caterpillar into a butterfly was amazing to watch.

content.meaning_en: Change in form, nature, or substance, especially to a higher form.
usage_sentences: The ancient alchemists tried to transmute lead into gold.
Art has the power to transmute pain into beauty.

content.meaning_en: Relating to speeds close to the speed of sound.
usage_sentences: An aircraft experiences significant aerodynamic effects as it approaches transonic speeds.
The engineers conducted tests in a transonic wind tunnel.

content.meaning_en: Situated or extending across something.
usage_sentences: A transverse beam provided support for the roof.
Light waves are a type of transverse wave.

content.meaning_en: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
usage_sentences: The trial was a travesty of justice, with a completely biased judge.
The movie was a travesty of the book it was based on.

content.meaning_en: The crime of betraying one's country.
usage_sentences: Benedict Arnold is infamous for committing treason during the American Revolution.
The spy was arrested and charged with treason.
content.origin: From Old French 'traison', from Latin 'traditio' (a handing over).

content.meaning_en: An involuntary quivering movement; a slight earthquake.
usage_sentences: A slight tremor ran through his hands as he waited nervously.
The earthquake was preceded by several small tremors.

content.meaning_en: A person entering someone's land or property without permission.
usage_sentences: The sign on the fence warned, 'Trespassers Will Be Prosecuted'.
The farmer was angry about the trespassers who left gates open.
content.origin: From 'trespass', from Old French 'trespasser' (to pass across).

content.meaning_en: A group of three related novels, plays, or films.
usage_sentences: The 'Lord of the Rings' is a famous fantasy trilogy by J.R.R. Tolkien.
She is currently writing the final book in her historical trilogy.

content.meaning_en: A group of three powerful or notable people jointly holding power or prominence.
usage_sentences: In ancient Rome, the First Triumvirate was a political alliance between Caesar, Pompey, and Crassus.
The company was successfully run by a triumvirate of its founding partners.
content.origin: From Latin 'triumviratus', from 'trium virum' (of three men).

content.meaning_en: The clothes, linen, and other belongings collected by a bride for her marriage.
usage_sentences: In traditional weddings, the bride's trousseau would be displayed for the guests.
She had been collecting items for her trousseau since she was a teenager.

content.meaning_en: A student who stays away from school without leave or explanation.
usage_sentences: The school called his parents to inform them he had been playing truant.
The attendance officer was looking for the chronic truant.

content.meaning_en: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
usage_sentences: He became truculent and aggressive when he drank too much.
Her truculent attitude made it difficult for her to work in a team.

content.meaning_en: A statement that is obviously true and says nothing new or interesting.
usage_sentences: He kept repeating the old truism that 'an apple a day keeps the doctor away'.
Her speech was full of empty truisms instead of real solutions.

content.meaning_en: A brass musical instrument; the loud cry of an elephant; to proclaim widely.
content.meaning_hi: तुरही; हाथी की चिंघाड़; डंका बजाना
usage_sentences: The elephant raised its trunk and let out a loud trumpet.
The company trumpeted its success in the annual report.
content.origin: From Old French 'trompette', a diminutive of 'trompe'.

content.meaning_en: A person who deserts one party or cause in order to join an opposing one.
usage_sentences: He was branded a turncoat by his former colleagues for joining the rival company.
The soldier was a turncoat who sold military secrets to the enemy.
content.origin: From the idea of turning one's coat inside out to hide the original color or insignia.

content.meaning_en: Protection of or authority over someone; guardianship; instruction.
usage_sentences: The young artist flourished under the tutelage of the great master.
As a minor, he was placed under the tutelage of his aunt.

content.meaning_en: A beginner or novice.
usage_sentences: Even a tyro in the kitchen can follow this simple recipe.
He was a tyro in the world of finance, but he learned quickly.

content.meaning_en: Without opposition; with the agreement of all people involved.
usage_sentences: The committee voted unanimously to approve the proposal.
She was unanimously elected as the new president of the club.

content.meaning_en: Not able to be gripped or held firmly.
usage_sentences: The wet, smooth rock was almost ungrippable.
His opponent's arm was so sweaty it became ungrippable.

content.meaning_en: Without special knowledge or experience.
usage_sentences: To the uninitiated, the technical jargon of the scientists was incomprehensible.
She explained the complex rules of the game for the benefit of the uninitiated.

content.meaning_en: Never done or known before.
usage_sentences: The company has experienced a period of unprecedented growth.
The pandemic created a situation that was unprecedented in modern history.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.
usage_sentences: The unscrupulous businessman cheated his partners out of their share of the profits.
She was a victim of an unscrupulous scam artist.

content.meaning_en: Difficult to carry or move because of its size, shape, or weight.
usage_sentences: He struggled to carry the large, unwieldy box up the stairs.
The old computer system was unwieldy and difficult to use.

content.meaning_en: An upward surge in the strength or quantity of something.
usage_sentences: There has been a recent upsurge in violent crime in the city.
The good economic news led to an upsurge in consumer confidence.

content.meaning_en: A tall, rounded vase with a base, used for storing ashes or as an ornament.
usage_sentences: After the cremation, his ashes were placed in a decorative urn.
A large ceramic urn stood in the corner of the garden.

content.meaning_en: A person who shows people to their seats; to show or guide someone somewhere.
usage_sentences: The usher guided us to our seats in the theater.
His discovery helped to usher in a new era of medicine.

content.meaning_en: A person who lends money at unreasonably high rates of interest.
usage_sentences: He fell into debt to a ruthless usurer who threatened him with violence.
In the past, usurers were often condemned by the church.
content.origin: From 'usury', from Latin 'usura' (a charge for use of money).

content.meaning_en: An imagined place or state of things in which everything is perfect.
usage_sentences: The novel describes a futuristic utopia where there is no poverty or war.
While a perfect utopia is impossible, we can still strive to create a better society.
content.origin: From Greek 'ou' (not) + 'topos' (place), coined by Sir Thomas More in his 1516 book 'Utopia'.

content.meaning_en: The killing of one's wife.
usage_sentences: He was found guilty of uxoricide and sentenced to life in prison.
The crime of uxoricide is a tragedy for any family.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).

content.meaning_en: Having or showing an excessive or submissive fondness for one's wife.
usage_sentences: His friends teased him for being so uxorious, always putting his wife's wishes first.
He was an uxorious husband who doted on his wife.

content.meaning_en: Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
usage_sentences: She continued to vacillate between the two job offers, unable to make a decision.
He would often vacillate on important issues, which made him seem like a weak leader.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless.
usage_sentences: He had a vacuous expression on his face, as if he didn't understand anything.
The movie was a vacuous comedy with a predictable plot.

content.meaning_en: A person who wanders from place to place without a home or job.
usage_sentences: He lived the life of a vagabond, traveling the country with no fixed destination.
The story is about a young vagabond who finds a home in an unexpected place.

content.meaning_en: A person without a settled home or regular work who wanders and lives by begging.
usage_sentences: The police moved the vagrants who were sleeping in the park.
He became a vagrant after losing his job and his home.

content.meaning_en: Having an excessively high opinion of one's appearance or worth; producing no result.
usage_sentences: She is very vain and spends hours looking at herself in the mirror.
All their efforts to save the company were in vain.

content.meaning_en: A person who is unduly anxious about their health.
usage_sentences: The old valetudinarian was always complaining about some new imaginary illness.
As a valetudinarian, she spent a lot of time reading medical books.

content.meaning_en: A person who deliberately destroys or damages public or private property.
content.meaning_hi: बर्बर; संपत्ति को नुकसान पहुँचाने वाला
usage_sentences: Vandals had smashed the windows of the school.
The police are looking for the vandals who spray-painted graffiti on the monument.
content.origin: From the Vandals, a Germanic people who sacked Rome in the 5th century.

content.meaning_en: The killing of a prophet.
usage_sentences: The ancient texts described the terrible crime of vaticide.
The followers were devastated by the vaticide of their beloved leader.
content.note: Suffix '-cide' refers to the act of killing (e.g., suicide, homicide).

content.meaning_en: Showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
usage_sentences: He was a vehement opponent of the new law.
She made a vehement denial of the charges against her.

content.meaning_en: A blood feud in which the family of a murdered person seeks vengeance; a prolonged bitter quarrel.
usage_sentences: The story of Romeo and Juliet is about a vendetta between two families.
He had a personal vendetta against his former business partner.

content.meaning_en: Accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age, wisdom, or character.
usage_sentences: The venerable old professor was an expert in his field.
They visited the venerable temple, which had stood for centuries.

content.meaning_en: (Of a fault or offence) slight and pardonable; excusable.
usage_sentences: Telling a small white lie is often considered a venial sin.
His mistake was a venial one and was easily forgiven.

content.meaning_en: An entertainer who can speak so that their voice seems to come from a dummy.
usage_sentences: The ventriloquist and his puppet put on a very funny show.
It takes a lot of skill to be a good ventriloquist.

content.meaning_en: A risky or daring journey or undertaking; to dare to do something risky.
usage_sentences: Starting a new business is always a risky venture.
No one would venture into the dark forest after sunset.

content.meaning_en: Conformity to facts; accuracy; habitual truthfulness.
usage_sentences: The police detective had to check the veracity of the witness's statement.
He was a man of great veracity, known for his honesty.

content.meaning_en: In exactly the same words as were used originally.
usage_sentences: She quoted the poem verbatim from memory.
The court reporter must record every word of the testimony verbatim.

content.meaning_en: Speech or writing that uses too many words or excessively technical expressions.
usage_sentences: The report was full of unnecessary verbiage and difficult to read.
Please cut out the verbiage and get to the point.

content.meaning_en: Using or expressed in more words than are needed.
usage_sentences: His writing style is very verbose and his sentences are often too long.
The verbose speaker went on for an hour, but said very little.

content.meaning_en: A left-hand page of an open book, or the back of a loose document.
usage_sentences: The author's photo was printed on the verso of the title page.
Please see the map on the verso for more details.

content.meaning_en: A service of evening prayer in the Western Christian Church.
usage_sentences: The monks gathered in the chapel every evening for vespers.
The sound of the choir singing vespers was beautiful.

content.meaning_en: A person who has had long experience in a particular field; a person who has served in the armed forces.
usage_sentences: He is a veteran of the software industry with over 30 years of experience.
The parade honored the brave veterans of the war.

content.meaning_en: Immoral or wicked behaviour; an immoral habit; a substitute.
usage_sentences: Gambling is a vice that has ruined many lives.
The Vice President will take over if the President is unable to serve.
content.origin: From Latin 'vitium' (a fault) and 'vicis' (a change, turn).

content.meaning_en: The area near or surrounding a particular place.
usage_sentences: There are no shops in the immediate vicinity of the hotel.
The police searched the vicinity for any clues.

content.meaning_en: Clear (someone) of blame or suspicion; show or prove to be right.
usage_sentences: The new evidence helped to vindicate the wrongly accused man.
The results of the experiment vindicated her theory.

content.meaning_en: Having or showing a strong or unreasoning desire for revenge.
usage_sentences: He was a vindictive person who would go to great lengths to harm his enemies.
She spread vindictive rumors about her ex-boyfriend.

content.meaning_en: A person highly skilled in music or another artistic pursuit.
usage_sentences: He was a piano virtuoso, known for his technical skill and passionate performances.
The orchestra featured a cello virtuoso as the guest soloist.

content.meaning_en: (Of a disease or poison) extremely severe or harmful; bitterly hostile.
usage_sentences: A particularly virulent strain of the flu caused a widespread epidemic.
He launched a virulent attack on his political opponent.

content.meaning_en: The cultivation of grapevines.
usage_sentences: The region is famous for its viticulture and produces award-winning wines.
He studied viticulture to learn how to grow the best grapes for winemaking.

content.meaning_en: (Especially of a woman) attractively lively and animated.
usage_sentences: She was a vivacious and energetic person who brought joy to everyone she met.
Her vivacious personality made her the life of the party.

content.meaning_en: (Of an animal) bringing forth live young which have developed inside the body.
usage_sentences: Most mammals, including humans, are viviparous.
Unlike most sharks, which are viviparous, some species lay eggs.

content.meaning_en: The faculty or power of using one's will; the act of making a conscious choice.
usage_sentences: He resigned from the company of his own volition, without any pressure from management.
She decided to quit smoking on her own volition.

content.meaning_en: A number of bullets, arrows, or missiles discharged at one time; a barrage.
usage_sentences: The archers fired a volley of arrows at the advancing army.
The reporters fired a volley of questions at the celebrity.

content.meaning_en: An abrupt and complete reversal of attitude, opinion, or policy.
usage_sentences: The politician did a complete volte-face on his earlier promises.
Her sudden volte-face on the issue surprised everyone.

content.meaning_en: Wanting or devouring great quantities of food; having a very eager approach to an activity.
usage_sentences: Growing teenagers often have a voracious appetite.
She was a voracious reader, finishing several books a week.

content.meaning_en: A long journey involving travel by sea or in space.
usage_sentences: Christopher Columbus embarked on a historic voyage across the Atlantic Ocean.
The spaceship's voyage to Mars took over six months.
content.origin: From Old French 'veiage', from Latin 'viaticum' (provision for a journey).

content.meaning_en: (Of a tail or finger) move rapidly to and fro; a person who makes jokes.
usage_sentences: The happy dog began to wag its tail excitedly.
He was known as the office wag, always ready with a clever joke.

content.meaning_en: A homeless and helpless person, especially a neglected or abandoned child.
usage_sentences: The story of Oliver Twist is about a poor street waif in London.
The kind woman took in the little waif and gave her a home.

content.meaning_en: A passage or path for walking along.
usage_sentences: A covered walkway connected the two buildings.
They strolled along the scenic walkway by the river.

content.meaning_en: A large cupboard in which clothes may be hung; a person's entire collection of clothes.
content.meaning_hi: अलमारी; किसी व्यक्ति के सारे कपड़े
usage_sentences: He hung his suits neatly in the wooden wardrobe.
She decided she needed a new wardrobe for the summer season.

content.meaning_en: (Archaic) The act or duty of watching; vigilance.
usage_sentences: The guards maintained their watchery over the castle walls all night.
A state of constant watchery was necessary to protect the border.

content.meaning_en: A list of passengers or goods carried by a vehicle.
usage_sentences: The truck driver had to present the waybill at every checkpoint.
The waybill listed all the cargo that was being transported.

content.meaning_en: Feeling or showing extreme tiredness; reluctant to experience any more of something.
usage_sentences: After a long day of hiking, the travelers were weary and ready for rest.
I have grown weary of his constant excuses.

content.meaning_en: Take or move somewhere suddenly and quickly; beat (eggs, cream) with a light, rapid movement.
usage_sentences: The celebrity was whisked away by her bodyguards before the reporters could ask questions.
You need to whisk the egg whites until they form stiff peaks.

content.meaning_en: Carve (wood) by repeatedly cutting small slices from it; reduce something in size by gradual steps.
usage_sentences: The old man sat on his porch, whittling a piece of wood into a small bird.
They managed to whittle down the list of candidates to just three.

content.meaning_en: (Of a plant) become limp through heat, loss of water, or disease; lose energy.
usage_sentences: The flowers began to wilt in the hot sun.
His enthusiasm for the project started to wilt after several setbacks.
content.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly related to a Dutch word for 'wither'.

content.meaning_en: A piece of unexpected good fortune, typically one involving money.
usage_sentences: He received an unexpected windfall when he inherited money from a distant relative.
The lottery win was a huge windfall for the family.
content.origin: Literally fruit blown down from a tree by the wind.

content.meaning_en: Blow a current of air through (grain) to remove chaff; separate desirable from undesirable parts.
usage_sentences: In the past, farmers would winnow the grain by tossing it in the air.
The committee had to winnow down a long list of applicants.

content.meaning_en: Great sorrow or distress; things that cause sorrow or distress.
usage_sentences: The city's financial woes were a major topic of discussion.
She told him a long tale of woe about her difficult life.

content.meaning_en: A dispute or argument, typically long and complicated; to engage in such a dispute.
usage_sentences: The legal wrangle over the inheritance lasted for years.
The two politicians would often wrangle over minor details.
content.origin: From a Low German word related to 'wring'.

content.meaning_en: An arrangement of flowers, leaves, or stems fastened in a ring.
usage_sentences: They laid a wreath of flowers on the soldier's grave.
People hang a festive wreath on their door at Christmas.

content.meaning_en: The remains of something that has been badly damaged or destroyed.
usage_sentences: Rescuers searched through the wreckage of the crashed plane.
The storm left a trail of wreckage in its path.

content.meaning_en: Twist and turn with quick writhing movements; avoid something by cleverness.
usage_sentences: The puppy tried to wriggle out of his arms.
He managed to wriggle out of his responsibilities.
content.origin: From Middle Low German or Middle Dutch 'wriggelen'.

content.meaning_en: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
usage_sentences: The rise in xenophobia was a worrying trend in the country.
Political leaders spoke out against racism and xenophobia.
content.note: Suffix '-phobia' denotes an extreme or irrational fear.

content.meaning_en: A feeling of intense longing for something.
usage_sentences: She felt a deep yearning for her childhood home.
He had a constant yearning for adventure and travel.
content.origin: From the verb 'yearn', from Old English 'giernan'.

content.meaning_en: A wooden crosspiece fastened over the necks of two animals to attach them to a plough; to join together.
usage_sentences: The farmer placed the yoke over the necks of the two oxen.
The people struggled to throw off the yoke of oppression.
content.origin: From Old English 'geoc', of Germanic origin.

content.meaning_en: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
usage_sentences: The religious zealot refused to listen to any opinion that differed from his own.
He was a political zealot, completely dedicated to his party's cause.

content.meaning_en: The time at which something is most powerful or successful; the highest point.
usage_sentences: The Roman Empire reached its zenith in the 2nd century AD.
Her career reached its zenith when she won the Oscar.
content.origin: From Old Spanish, from Arabic 'samt (ar-ra's)', meaning 'path (over the head)'.

content.meaning_en: A belt of the heavens divided into twelve equal signs, used in astrology.
usage_sentences: Each of the twelve signs of the zodiac is associated with a different constellation.
The astrologer asked for his birth date to determine his sign of the zodiac.

content.meaning_en: A person who walks about in their sleep.
usage_sentences: The clinic treats patients who are somnambulists.
Shakespeare's Lady Macbeth is a famous fictional somnambulist.

content.meaning_en: Present everywhere at the same time.
usage_sentences: To a child, a loving mother is an omnipresent force.
The problem of pollution has become omnipresent in the modern world.

content.meaning_en: A person who knows and is able to use several languages.
usage_sentences: The tour guide was a polyglot, fluently switching between languages.
As a polyglot, she found it easy to work for international organizations.

content.meaning_en: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
usage_sentences: After years of betrayal, he became a bitter misanthrope.
The main character is a wealthy misanthrope who prefers books.

content.meaning_en: A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by generous donations.
usage_sentences: The new hospital wing was funded by a wealthy philanthropist.
She was a noted philanthropist, dedicating her fortune to education.

content.meaning_en: A person who collects or has a great love of books.
usage_sentences: His massive library was a clear indication he was a true bibliophile.
The old bibliophile spent weekends searching for rare first editions.

content.meaning_en: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
usage_sentences: While he is a great expert, his advice is not infallible.
The new computer system was marketed as being completely infallible.
content.origin: From late Latin 'infallibilis', from 'in-' (not) and 'fallibilis' (liable to err).

content.meaning_en: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
usage_sentences: With those dark clouds gathering, rain seems inevitable.
Change is an inevitable part of life.

content.meaning_en: A connoisseur of good food; a person with a discerning palate.
usage_sentences: The restaurant is a favorite among local gourmets.
He considered himself a gourmet, delighting in exotic meals.

content.meaning_en: A person who never drinks alcohol.
usage_sentences: He was a strict teetotaler and only drank water at parties.
The organization was founded by a group of dedicated teetotalers.
content.origin: From the mid-19th century, from the emphatic use of the letter 'T' in 'total'.

content.meaning_en: A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining.
usage_sentences: She remained a stoic throughout her long illness.
The old soldier had a stoic expression on his face as he received the news.
content.origin: From Greek 'Stōïkos', referring to the 'Stoa Poikilē' in Athens where Zeno taught.

content.meaning_en: A person who has a selfless concern for the well-being of others.
usage_sentences: The nurse was a true altruist, often working extra shifts without pay.
An altruist by nature, she dedicated her life to helping the homeless.
content.origin: From French 'altruisme', formed from Italian 'altrui' (of others).

content.meaning_en: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
usage_sentences: He was a fastidious writer, often spending hours on a single sentence.
Her fastidious attention to detail made her an excellent editor.

content.meaning_en: A person or their tendencies not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
